body_markdown:
Here is a simple tutorial on how to set up an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) like Visual Studio Code (VS Code) for a Machine Learning (ML) / Artificial Intelligence (AI) project, using Python and some common ML libraries. This tutorial assumes that Python and VS Code are already installed on your computer.

---

# Setting Up VS Code for a ML/AI Project

This guide will walk you through the process of setting up an IDE (Visual Studio Code) for your machine learning or artificial intelligence project.

## Prerequisites

- Python (3.6 or later)
- Visual Studio Code

If you don't have these installed, please refer to these guides:

- [Download Python](https://www.python.org/downloads/)
- [Download Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/download)

## Step 1: Install the Python extension

After installing VS Code, you need to install the Python extension. This can be found in the VS Code marketplace by typing "Python" in the search bar. Click on install.

```markdown
![Python Extension](https://example.com/path/to/image.png)
```

## Step 2: Set up a virtual environment

In your terminal or command prompt, navigate to your project folder and create a virtual environment. Virtual environments allow you to keep your project dependencies isolated from other projects.

For Unix or MacOS:

```shell
python3 -m venv venv
```

For Windows:

```powershell
py -m venv venv
```

This creates a folder called `venv` in your project folder.

## Step 3: Activate the virtual environment

Before you can use the virtual environment, you need to activate it.

For Unix or MacOS:

```shell
source venv/bin/activate
```

For Windows:

```powershell
.\venv\Scripts\activate
```

You will know that you're in the virtual environment when you see `(venv)` at the beginning of your command prompt line.

## Step 4: Install necessary packages

With the virtual environment activated, you can now install the packages you need for your project.

```shell
pip install numpy pandas scikit-learn tensorflow
```

This command installs numpy, pandas, scikit-learn, and tensorflow. You may replace these with the packages you need for your project.

## Step 5: Set up the Python interpreter in VS Code

In VS Code, click on `View -> Command Palette`, then search for `Python: Select Interpreter`. Choose the interpreter that corresponds to the virtual environment you set up earlier.

```markdown
![Select Interpreter](https://example.com/path/to/image.png)
```

## Step 6: Create and run a Python file

To test everything, create a new Python file, import one of the libraries you installed, and run some code.

```python
import tensorflow as tf

# Create a constant op
const = tf.constant("Hello, TensorFlow!")

# Run the op
print(const)
```

Click on `Run -> Start Debugging` or press `F5` to run your code.

```markdown
![Run Code](https://example.com/path/to/image.png)
```

If you see "Hello, TensorFlow!" printed to the console, congratulations! You have successfully set up your IDE for your ML/AI project.

---

## References

1. [Python in Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/python)
2. [Python Virtual Environments](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/venv.html)
3. [TensorFlow](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip)

---

Please note that the provided image links are placeholders and need to be replaced with the actual images.

Also, different ML/AI projects may

Linked: [https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18091](https://www.stackoverflow.com/)

body_markdown:
# An Introduction to Machine Learning

- [What Is Machine Learning?](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#what-is-machine-learning)

- [How Does It Work?](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#how-it-works)

- [Machine Learning Tools](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#machine-learning-tools)

![Machine learning](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/2c65ca243cc5335e89d5f770dbc2e45c3ce22f9f/3ad94/static/bff9b389f4dd53ddc33471b1092ab5ba/50bf7/main.png "Machine learning")

The term machine learning was first coined in the 1950s when [Artificial Intelligence pioneer Arthur Samuel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Samuel) built the first self-learning system for playing checkers. He noticed that the more the system played, the better it performed.

Fueled by advances in statistics and computer science, as well as [better datasets](https://qz.com/1034972/the-data-that-changed-the-direction-of-ai-research-and-possibly-the-world/) and the [growth of neural networks](https://eos.org/agu-news/the-rise-of-machine-learning), machine learning has truly taken off in recent years.

Today, whether you realize it or not, [machine learning is everywhere](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/machine-learning-applications/) ‒ automated translation, image recognition, voice search technology, self-driving cars, and beyond.

In this guide, we’ll explain how machine learning works and how you can use it in your business. We’ll also introduce you to [machine learning tools](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/machine-learning-tools/) and show you how to get started with [no-code machine learning](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/no-code-machine-learning/).

Read along, skip to a section, or bookmark this post for later:

1. [What Is Machine Learning?](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#what-is-machine-learning)

2. [Types of Machine Learning](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#machine-learning-types)

3. [How Machine Learning Works](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#how-it-works)

4. [Machine Learning Use Cases](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#machine-learning-uses)

5. [Get Started With Machine Learning Tools](https://monkeylearn.com/machine-learning/#machine-learning-tools)

## What Is Machine Learning?

![](data:image/png;base64,)![What is ML?](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/bb286fbd32c6962d06a35bea41071512b8dd9735/68277/static/56ecffb7165ec68273e08ad553dda523/e4918/what-is-machine-learning.jpg)

Machine learning (ML) is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that enables computers to “self-learn” from training data and improve over time, without being explicitly programmed. [Machine learning algorithms](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/machine-learning-algorithms/) are able to detect patterns in data and learn from them, in order to make their own predictions. In short, machine learning algorithms and models learn through experience.

In traditional programming, a computer engineer writes a series of directions that instruct a computer how to transform input data into a desired output. Instructions are mostly based on an IF-THEN structure: when certain conditions are met, the program executes a specific action.

Machine learning, on the other hand, is an automated process that enables machines to solve problems with little or no human input, and take actions based on past observations.

While [artificial intelligence and machine learning](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/nlp-ai/) are often used interchangeably, they are two different concepts. AI is the broader concept – machines making decisions, learning new skills, and solving problems in a similar way to humans – whereas machine learning is a subset of AI that enables intelligent systems to autonomously learn new things from data.

Instead of programming machine learning algorithms to perform tasks, you can feed them examples of labeled data (known as [training data](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/training-data/)), which helps them make calculations, process data, and identify patterns automatically.

Put simply, Google’s Chief Decision Scientist describes machine learning as [a fancy labeling machine](https://hackernoon.com/six-useful-metaphors-for-thinking-about-artificial-intelligence-c7468b1551fa). After teaching machines to label things like apples and pears, by showing them examples of fruit, eventually they will start labeling apples and pears without any help – provided they have learned from appropriate and accurate training examples.

Machine learning can be put to work on massive amounts of data and can perform much more accurately than humans. It can help you save time and money on tasks and analyses, like [solving customer pain points](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/customer-pain-points/) to improve customer satisfaction, [support ticket automation](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/ticket-classification-with-ai/), and [data mining](https://monkeylearn.com/text-mining/) from internal sources and all over the internet.

But what’s behind the machine learning process?

## Types of Machine Learning

![](data:image/png;base64,)![Types of machine learning](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/bf53082cd74ce4289ea9e633d52a86ac226bb467/9f692/static/00d97fa74ccf3ae99e95febc7b85f11c/e4918/types.jpg)

To understand how machine learning works, you’ll need to explore different machine learning methods and algorithms, which are basically sets of rules that machines use to make decisions. Below, you’ll find the five most common and most used types of machine learning:

### Supervised Learning

[Supervised learning algorithms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervised_learning) and supervised learning models make predictions based on labeled training data. Each training sample includes an input and a desired output. A supervised learning algorithm analyzes this sample data and makes an inference – basically, an educated guess when determining the labels for unseen data.

This is the most common and popular approach to machine learning. It’s “supervised” because these models need to be fed manually tagged sample data to learn from. Data is labeled to tell the machine what patterns (similar words and images, data categories, etc.) it should be looking for and recognize connections with.

For example, if you want to automatically detect spam, you would need to feed a machine learning algorithm examples of emails that you want classified as spam and others that are important, and should not be considered spam.

Which brings us to our next point – the two types of supervised learning tasks: *classification* and *regression*.

#### Classification in supervised machine learning

There are a number of [classification algorithms](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/classification-algorithms/) used in supervised learning, with [Support Vector Machines (SVM)](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/introduction-to-support-vector-machines-svm/) and [Naive Bayes](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/practical-explanation-naive-bayes-classifier/) among the most common.

In classification tasks, the output value is a category with a finite number of options. For example, with this [free pre-trained sentiment analysis model](https://monkeylearn.com/sentiment-analysis-online/), you can automatically classify data as positive, negative, or neutral.

Let’s say you want to analyze customer support conversations to understand your clients’ emotions: are they happy or frustrated after contacting your customer service team? A [sentiment analysis](https://monkeylearn.com/sentiment-analysis/) classifier can automatically tag responses for you, like in the below:

### Test with your own text

Classify Text

### Results

TAGCONFIDENCE

Negative99.7%

In this example, a sentiment analysis model tags a frustrating customer support experience as *“Negative”*.

#### Regression in supervised machine learning

In regression tasks, the expected result is a continuous number. This model is used to predict quantities, such as the probability an event will happen, meaning the output may have any number value within a certain range. Predicting the value of a property in a specific neighborhood or the spread of COVID19 in a particular region are examples of regression problems.

### Unsupervised Learning

[Unsupervised learning algorithms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unsupervised_learning) uncover insights and relationships in unlabeled data. In this case, models are fed input data but the desired outcomes are unknown, so they have to make inferences based on circumstantial evidence, without any guidance or training. The models are not trained with the “right answer,” so they must find patterns on their own.

One of the most common types of unsupervised learning is clustering, which consists of grouping similar data. This method is mostly used for exploratory analysis and can help you detect hidden patterns or trends.

For example, the marketing team of an e-commerce company could [use clustering to improve customer segmentation](https://bdtechtalks.com/2020/12/28/machine-learning-customer-segmentation/). Given a set of income and spending data, a machine learning model can identify groups of customers with similar behaviors.

Segmentation allows marketers to tailor strategies for each key market. They might offer promotions and discounts for low-income customers that are high spenders on the site, as a way to reward loyalty and improve retention.

### Semi-Supervised Learning

In [semi-supervised learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-supervised_learning), training data is split into two. A small amount of labeled data and a larger set of unlabeled data.

In this case, the model uses labeled data as an input to make inferences about the unlabeled data, providing more accurate results than regular supervised-learning models.

This approach is gaining popularity, especially for tasks involving large datasets such as image classification. Semi-supervised learning doesn’t require a large number of labeled data, so it’s faster to set up, more cost-effective than supervised learning methods, and ideal for businesses that receive huge amounts of data.

### Reinforcement Learning

[Reinforcement learning (RL)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning) is concerned with how a software agent (or computer program) ought to act in a situation to maximize the reward. In short, reinforced machine learning models attempt to determine the best possible path they should take in a given situation. They do this through trial and error. Since there is no training data, machines learn from their own mistakes and choose the actions that lead to the best solution or maximum reward.

This machine learning method is mostly used in robotics and gaming. Video games demonstrate a clear relationship between actions and results, and can measure success by keeping score. Therefore, they’re a great way to improve reinforcement learning algorithms.

### Deep Learning (DL)

[Deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning) models can be supervised, semi-supervised, or unsupervised (or a combination of any or all of the three). They’re advanced machine learning algorithms used by tech giants, like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon to run entire systems and power things, like self driving cars and smart assistants.

![](data:image/png;base64,)![A diagram showing the progression from Artificial Intelligence, to Machine Learning, to Deep Learning from the 1950s to modern day.](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/63553ee725acd0218379770d399a64bbaea83109/a3971/static/83ef48b5cf3020a618d878835a6d2167/41b2a/image12.png)

Deep learning is based on [Artificial Neural Networks (ANN)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_neural_network), a type of computer system that emulates the way the human brain works. Deep learning algorithms or neural networks are built with multiple layers of interconnected neurons, allowing multiple systems to work together simultaneously, and step-by-step.

When a model receives input data ‒ which could be image, text, video, or audio ‒ and is asked to perform a task (for example, [text classification with machine learning](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/text-classification-machine-learning/)), the data passes through every layer, enabling the model to learn progressively. It’s kind of like a human brain that evolves with age and experience!

Deep learning is common in image recognition, speech recognition, and [Natural Language Processing (NLP)](https://monkeylearn.com/natural-language-processing/). Deep learning models usually perform better than other machine learning algorithms for complex problems and massive sets of data. However, they generally require millions upon millions of pieces of training data, so it takes quite a lot of time to train them.

## How Machine Learning Works

![](data:image/png;base64,)![How it Works](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/7924a51c181551cf9a9b32c34f9ffd5c9c72d509/cfc45/static/1f82dcd2399e05c4e7aa9b7f9c1aac69/e4918/how-it-works.jpg)

In order to understand how machine learning works, first you need to know what a “tag” is. To train image recognition, for example, you would “tag” photos of dogs, cats, horses, etc., with the appropriate animal name. This is also called [data labeling](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/data-labeling/).

![](data:image/png;base64,)![Showing how a kitten image is labeled, so a machine learning model can recognize other kitten images and label them correctly.](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/aca9a68541d9454c63f3a57a20bd22d643d3cc6e/8fe3f/static/24daa8033dc87608b8544bb20b247ddb/95da0/image-classification.png)

When working with [machine learning text analysis](https://monkeylearn.com/text-analysis/), you would feed a text analysis model with text training data, then tag it, depending on what kind of analysis you’re doing. If you’re working with sentiment analysis, you would feed the model with [customer feedback](https://monkeylearn.com/customer-feedback/), for example, and train the model by tagging each comment as Positive, Neutral, and Negative.

Take a look at the diagram below:

![](data:image/png;base64,)![A diagram showing how training a machine learning text analysis model works.](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/426ec3f7d3a414adecc2890677d79c4ae14be795/59e63/static/74491b164c59b243e5f6d601c0365fbf/ebbb8/ml-process.png)

At its most simplistic, the machine learning process involves three steps:

1. Feed a machine learning model training input data. In our case, this could be customer comments from social media or customer service data.

2. Tag training data with a desired output. In this case, tell your sentiment analysis model whether each comment or piece of data is *Positive, Neutral,* or *Negative*. The model transforms the training data into [text vectors](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/beginners-guide-text-vectorization/) – numbers that represent data features.

3. Test your model by feeding it testing (or unseen) data. Algorithms are trained to associate feature vectors with tags based on manually tagged samples, then learn to make predictions when processing unseen data.

If your new model performs to your standards and criteria after testing it, it’s ready to be put to work on all kinds of new data. If it’s not performing accurately, you’ll need to keep training. Furthermore, as human language and industry-specific language morphs and changes, you may need to continually train your model with new information.

## Machine Learning Use Cases

![](data:image/png;base64,)![Applications](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/f439bef1209d3166831f31558e5b8569450de32a/579e8/static/45045437eb6f2392b12d432a90644875/e4918/machine-learning-applications.jpg)

[Machine learning applications](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/machine-learning-applications/) and use cases are nearly endless, especially as we begin to work from home more (or have [hybrid offices](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-15/boe-says-work-after-covid-will-be-done-both-in-home-and-offices)), become more tied to our smartphones, and use machine learning-guided technology to get around.

[Machine learning in finance](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/machine-learning-in-finance/), healthcare, hospitality, government, and beyond, is already in regular use. Businesses are beginning to see the benefits of using machine learning tools to improve their processes, gain valuable insights from [unstructured data](https://monkeylearn.com/unstructured-data/), and automate tasks that would otherwise require hours of tedious, manual work (which usually produces much less accurate results).

For example, [UberEats uses machine learning](https://thenewstack.io/how-uber-eats-uses-machine-learning-to-estimate-delivery-times/) to estimate optimum times for drivers to pick up food orders, while [Spotify leverages machine learning to offer personalized content](https://labs.spotify.com/2020/01/16/for-your-ears-only-personalizing-spotify-home-with-machine-learning/) and [personalized marketing](https://blog.snappymob.com/spotify-wrapped-personalized-marketing-done-right). And [Dell uses machine learning text analysis](https://monkeylearn.com/customers/dell) to save hundreds of hours analyzing thousands of employee surveys to listen to the [voice of employee (VoE)](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/voice-of-employee/) and improve employee satisfaction.

How do you think [Google Maps predicts peaks in traffic](https://www.cnet.com/news/heres-how-google-maps-uses-ai-to-predict-traffic-and-calculate-routes/) and Netflix creates personalized movie recommendations, [even informs the creation of new content](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/shannonkeating/ginny-georgia-netflix-season-1-review) ? By using machine learning, of course.

There are many different applications of machine learning, which can benefit your business in countless ways. You’ll just need to define a strategy to help you decide the best way to implement machine learning into your existing processes. In the meantime, here are some common machine learning use cases and applications that might spark some ideas:

- Social Media Monitoring

- Customer Service & Customer Satisfaction

- Image Recognition

- Virtual Assistants

- Product Recommendations

- Stock Market Trading

- Medical Diagnosis

### Social Media Monitoring

[Using machine learning you can monitor mentions of your brand on social media](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/analyzing-customer-support-interactions-on-twitter-with-machine-learning/) and immediately identify if customers require urgent attention. By detecting mentions from angry customers, in real-time, you can [automatically tag customer feedback](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/auto-tagging-customer-feedback-with-machine-learning/) and respond right away. You might also want to analyze customer support interactions on social media and gauge [customer satisfaction (CSAT)](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/csat-calculation/), to see how well your team is performing.

[Natural Language Processing](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/nlp-python/) gives machines the ability to break down spoken or written language much like a human would, to process “natural” language, so machine learning can handle text from practically any source.

### Customer Service & Customer Satisfaction

Machine learning allows you to [integrate powerful text analysis tools with customer support tools](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/zendesk-machine-learning/), so you can analyze your emails, live chats, and all manner of internal data on the go. You can use machine learning to tag support tickets and route them to the correct teams or auto-respond to common queries so you never leave a customer in the cold.

Furthermore, using machine learning to set up a [voice of customer (VoC) program](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/voice-of-customer-program/) and a [customer feedback loop](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/customer-feedback-loop/) will ensure that you follow the customer journey from start to finish to improve the customer experience (CX), [decrease customer churn](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/customer-churn-analysis/), and, ultimately, increase your profits.

### Image Recognition

Image recognition is helping companies identify and classify images. For example, [facial recognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_recognition_system) technology is being used as a form of identification, from unlocking phones to [making payments](https://news.yahoo.com/facial-recognition-payments-rolled-russia-132117843.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAALNtRv5uWrd8hRSE60AldUxuED2Q1gKcmO9_NUdcKLJvuPAX23STUavdKYLR7cKIydB89adb_9Lm9eiU5XjF1h63QPbD35zJKbn8bfd9yhTg3pjlZyubtDD4ivh7vGNhRCleToUEEf69rAiRAYzjKbrklfxy6jWQcs5KyHqQnPVk).

Self-driving cars also use image recognition to perceive space and obstacles. For example, they can learn to recognize stop signs, identify intersections, and make decisions based on what they see.

### Virtual Assistants

Virtual assistants, like Siri, Alexa, Google Now, all make use of machine learning to automatically process and answer voice requests. They quickly scan information, remember related queries, learn from previous interactions, and send commands to other apps, so they can collect information and deliver the most effective answer.

Customer support teams are already using virtual assistants to handle phone calls, [automatically route support tickets](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/automatically-route-customer-support-tickets-to-the-most-appropriate-person/), to the correct teams, and speed up interactions with customers via computer-generated responses.

### Product Recommendations

[Association rule-learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_rule_learning) is a machine learning technique that can be used to analyze purchasing habits at the supermarket or on e-commerce sites. It works by searching for relationships between variables and finding common associations in transactions (products that consumers usually buy together). This data is then used for product placement strategies and similar product recommendations.

Associated rules can also be useful to plan a marketing campaign or analyze web usage.

### Stock Market Trading

Machine learning algorithms can be trained to identify trading opportunities, by recognizing patterns and behaviors in historical data. Humans are often driven by emotions when it comes to making investments, so [sentiment analysis with machine learning](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/sentiment-analysis-machine-learning/) can play a huge role in identifying good and bad investing opportunities, with no human bias, whatsoever. They can even save time and [allow traders more time away from their screens by automating tasks](https://www.finextra.com/blogposting/20028/how-is-ai-revolutionizing-fx-market-in-a-way-we-didnt-even-realize).

### Medical Diagnosis

The ability of machines to find patterns in complex data is shaping the present and future. Take [machine learning initiatives during the COVID-19 outbreak](https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/348368), for instance. AI tools have helped predict how the virus will spread over time, and shaped how we control it. It’s also helped diagnose patients by analyzing lung CTs and detecting fevers using facial recognition, and identified patients at a higher risk of developing serious respiratory disease.

Machine learning is driving innovation in many fields, and every day we’re seeing new interesting use cases emerge. In business, the overall benefits of machine learning include:

- **It’s cost-effective and scalable.** You only need to train a machine learning model once, and you can scale up or down depending on how much data you receive.

- **Performs more accurately than humans.** Machine learning models are trained with a certain amount of labeled data and will use it to make predictions on unseen data. Based on this data, machines define a set of rules that they apply to all datasets, helping them provide consistent and accurate results. No need to worry about human error or innate bias. And you can train the tools to the needs and criteria of your business.

- **Works in real-time, 24/7.** Machine learning models can automatically analyze data in real-time, allowing you to immediately detect negative opinions or urgent tickets and take action.

## Get Started With Machine Learning Tools

![](data:image/png;base64,)![How to Get Started](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/dbf56c77075ae541268fb144e637253a6e30c8cd/24f84/static/d991f222f3d3be2ac3fbad7277e9a0ad/e4918/tools.jpg)

When you’re ready to get started with machine learning tools it comes down to the [Build vs. Buy Debate](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/build-vs-buy/). If you have a data science and computer engineering background or are prepared to hire whole teams of coders and computer scientists, building your own with open-source libraries can produce great results. Building your own tools, however, can take months or years and cost in the tens of thousands.

Using SaaS or [MLaaS (Machine Learning as a Service)](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/mlaas/) tools, on the other hand, is much cheaper because you only pay what you use. They can also be implemented right away and new platforms and techniques make SaaS tools just as powerful, scalable, customizable, and accurate as building your own.

Whether you choose to build or buy you machine learning tools, here are some of the best of each:

### Top SaaS Machine Learning Tools

Some of the best SaaS machine learning tools on the market:

- MonkeyLearn

- BigML

- IBM Watson

- Google Cloud ML

#### MonkeyLearn

[MonkeyLearn](https://monkeylearn.com/) is a powerful SaaS machine learning platform with a suite of text analysis tools to get real-time insights and powerful results, so you can make data-driven decisions from all manner of text data: customer service interactions, social media comments, online reviews, emails, live chats, and more.

Just connect your data and use one of the pre-trained machine learning models to start analyzing it. You can even build your own no-code machine learning models in a few simple steps, and integrate them with the apps you use every day, like Zendesk, Google Sheets and more.

![](data:image/png;base64,)![How MonkeyLearn's machine learning models work: Import data, train your model and analyze data, automate your processes.](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/857de7bc0c82aa3dcbe8c8b4ec1999412c80fdf9/a2208/static/9d0316781b383fc8ddcf2320e43b87db/f6ee6/how-monkeylearn-works.jpg)

MonkeyLearn is scalable to handle any amount of data – from just a few hundred surveys, to hundreds of thousands of comments from all over the web – to get real-world results from your data with techniques, like [topic analysis](https://monkeylearn.com/topic-analysis/), [sentiment analysis](https://monkeylearn.com/sentiment-analysis/), [text extraction](https://monkeylearn.com/keyword-extraction/), and more.

And you can take your analysis even further with [MonkeyLearn Studio](https://monkeylearn.com/monkeylearn-studio/) to combine your analyses to work together. It’s a seamless process to take you from data collection to analysis to striking visualization in a single, easy-to-use dashboard.

Take a look at this MonkeyLearn Studio [aspect-based sentiment analysis](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/aspect-based-sentiment-analysis/) of online reviews of Zoom:

![](data:image/png;base64,)![The MonkeyLearn Studio dashboard showing multiple text analysis results together.](https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/f5d9c481abfcc1f37c469f25face33f606bc3b0f/672f5/static/2004075dc4ded261b09ccc5b0165c580/988a9/ml-studio.png)

Aspect-based sentiment analysis first categorizes the customer opinions by “aspect” (topic or subject): *Usability, Reliability, Pricing,* etc. Each comment is then sentiment analyzed to show whether it’s *Positive, Negative,* or *Neutral*. This allows you to see which aspects of your business are particularly positive and which are negative.

Other techniques, like [intent classification](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/intent-classification/) are especially useful for incoming emails or social media inquiries to automatically show why the customer is writing. Also, at the bottom right you can see [word clouds](https://monkeylearn.com/blog/word-cloud-tools/) that show the most used and most important words and phrases by sentiment.

[MonkeyLearn pricing](https://monkeylearn.com/pricing/).

#### BigML

The goal of [BigML](https://bigml.com/) is to connect all of your company’s data streams and internal processes to simplify collaboration and analysis results across the organization. They specialize in industries, like aerospace, automotive, energy, entertainment, financial services, food, healthcare, IoT, pharmaceutical, transportation, telecommunications, and more, so many of their tools are ready to go, right out of the box.

You can use pre-trained models or train your own with classification and regression and time series forecasting.

[BigML pricing](https://bigml.com/pricing)

#### IBM Watson

[IBM Watson](https://www.ibm.com/watson) is a machine learning juggernaut, offering adaptability to most industries and the ability to build to huge scale across any cloud.

Watson Speech-to-Text is one of the industry standards for converting real-time spoken language to text, and Watson Language Translator is one of the best text translation tools on the market.

Watson Studio is great for data preparation and analysis and can be customized to almost any field, and their Natural Language Classifier makes building advanced SaaS analysis models easy.

See [products page](https://www.ibm.com/watson/products-services) for pricing.

#### Google Cloud ML

[Google Cloud ML](https://cloud.google.com/solutions/ai/) is a SaaS analysis solution for image and text that connects easily to all of Google’s tools: Gmail, Google Sheets, Google Slides, Google Docs, and more.

Google AutoML Natural Language is one of the most advanced text analysis tools on the market, and AutoML Vision allows you to automate the training of custom image analysis models for some of the best accuracy, regardless of your needs.

[Google Cloud AI and ML pricing](https://cloud.google.com/pricing/list)

### Top Open Source Libraries for Machine Learning

Open source machine learning libraries offer collections of pre-made models and components that developers can use to build their own applications, instead of having to code from scratch. They are free, flexible, and can be customized to meet specific needs.

Some of the most popular open-source libraries for machine learning include:

- Scikit-learn

- PyTorch

- Kaggle

- NLTK

- TensorFlow

#### Scikit-learn

[Scikit-learn](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/) is a popular Python library and a great option for those who are just starting out with machine learning. Why? It’s easy to use, robust, and [very well documented](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/tutorial/index.html). You can use this library for tasks such as classification, clustering, and regression, among others.

#### PyTorch

Developed by Facebook, [PyTorch](https://pytorch.org/) is an open source machine learning library based on the Torch library with a focus on deep learning. It’s used for computer vision and natural language processing, and is much better at debugging than some of its competitors. If you want to start out with PyTorch, there are easy-to-follow [tutorials](https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/) for both beginners and advanced coders. Known for its flexibility and speed, it’s ideal if you need a quick solution.

#### Kaggle

Launched over a decade ago (and acquired by Google in 2017), Kaggle has a learning-by-doing philosophy, and it’s renowned for its competitions in which participants create models to solve real problems. Check out this [online machine learning course in Python](https://www.kaggle.com/learn/intro-to-machine-learning), which will have you building your first model in next to no time.

#### NLTK

The [Natural Language Toolkit (NLTK)](https://www.nltk.org/) is possibly the best known Python library for working with natural language processing. It can be used for keyword search, tokenization and classification, voice recognition and more. With a heavy focus on research and education, you’ll find plenty of resources, including data sets, pre-trained models, and a textbook to help you get started.

#### TensorFlow

An open-source Python library developed by Google for internal use and then released under an open license, with tons of resources, tutorials, and tools to help you hone your machine learning skills. Suitable for both beginners and experts, this user-friendly platform has all you need to build and train machine learning models (including a [library of pre-trained models](https://www.tensorflow.org/hub)). Tensorflow is more powerful than other libraries and focuses on deep learning, making it perfect for complex projects with large-scale data. However, it may take time and skills to master. Like with most open-source tools, it has a strong community and some [tutorials](https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials) to help you get started.

## Final Note

MonkeyLearn offers [simple integrations with tools you already use](https://monkeylearn.com/integrations/), like Zendesk, Freshdesk, SurveyMonkey, Google Apps, Zapier, Rapidminer, and more, to streamline processes, save time, and increase internal (and external) communication.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning
body:
An Introduction to Machine Learning

  • What Is Machine Learning?

  • How Does It Work?

  • Machine Learning Tools

The term machine learning was first coined in the 1950s when Artificial Intelligence pioneer Arthur Samuel built the first self-learning system for playing checkers. He noticed that the more the system played, the better it performed.

Fueled by advances in statistics and computer science, as well as better datasets and the growth of neural networks, machine learning has truly taken off in recent years.

Today, whether you realize it or not, machine learning is everywhere ‒ automated translation, image recognition, voice search technology, self-driving cars, and beyond.

In this guide, we’ll explain how machine learning works and how you can use it in your business. We’ll also introduce you to machine learning tools and show you how to get started with no-code machine learning.

Read along, skip to a section, or bookmark this post for later:

  1. What Is Machine Learning?

  2. Types of Machine Learning

  3. How Machine Learning Works

  4. Machine Learning Use Cases

  5. Get Started With Machine Learning Tools

What Is Machine Learning?

Machine learning (ML) is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that enables computers to “self-learn” from training data and improve over time, without being explicitly programmed. Machine learning algorithms are able to detect patterns in data and learn from them, in order to make their own predictions. In short, machine learning algorithms and models learn through experience.

In traditional programming, a computer engineer writes a series of directions that instruct a computer how to transform input data into a desired output. Instructions are mostly based on an IF-THEN structure: when certain conditions are met, the program executes a specific action.

Machine learning, on the other hand, is an automated process that enables machines to solve problems with little or no human input, and take actions based on past observations.

While artificial intelligence and machine learning are often used interchangeably, they are two different concepts. AI is the broader concept – machines making decisions, learning new skills, and solving problems in a similar way to humans – whereas machine learning is a subset of AI that enables intelligent systems to autonomously learn new things from data.

Instead of programming machine learning algorithms to perform tasks, you can feed them examples of labeled data (known as training data), which helps them make calculations, process data, and identify patterns automatically.

Put simply, Google’s Chief Decision Scientist describes machine learning as a fancy labeling machine. After teaching machines to label things like apples and pears, by showing them examples of fruit, eventually they will start labeling apples and pears without any help – provided they have learned from appropriate and accurate training examples.

Machine learning can be put to work on massive amounts of data and can perform much more accurately than humans. It can help you save time and money on tasks and analyses, like solving customer pain points to improve customer satisfaction, support ticket automation, and data mining from internal sources and all over the internet.

But what’s behind the machine learning process?

Types of Machine Learning

To understand how machine learning works, you’ll need to explore different machine learning methods and algorithms, which are basically sets of rules that machines use to make decisions. Below, you’ll find the five most common and most used types of machine learning:

Supervised Learning

Supervised learning algorithms and supervised learning models make predictions based on labeled training data. Each training sample includes an input and a desired output. A supervised learning algorithm analyzes this sample data and makes an inference – basically, an educated guess when determining the labels for unseen data.

This is the most common and popular approach to machine learning. It’s “supervised” because these models need to be fed manually tagged sample data to learn from. Data is labeled to tell the machine what patterns (similar words and images, data categories, etc.) it should be looking for and recognize connections with.

For example, if you want to automatically detect spam, you would need to feed a machine learning algorithm examples of emails that you want classified as spam and others that are important, and should not be considered spam.

Which brings us to our next point – the two types of supervised learning tasks: classification and regression.

Classification in supervised machine learning

There are a number of classification algorithms used in supervised learning, with Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Naive Bayes among the most common.

In classification tasks, the output value is a category with a finite number of options. For example, with this free pre-trained sentiment analysis model, you can automatically classify data as positive, negative, or neutral.

Let’s say you want to analyze customer support conversations to understand your clients’ emotions: are they happy or frustrated after contacting your customer service team? A sentiment analysis classifier can automatically tag responses for you, like in the below:

Test with your own text

Classify Text

Results

TAGCONFIDENCE

Negative99.7%

In this example, a sentiment analysis model tags a frustrating customer support experience as “Negative”.

Regression in supervised machine learning

In regression tasks, the expected result is a continuous number. This model is used to predict quantities, such as the probability an event will happen, meaning the output may have any number value within a certain range. Predicting the value of a property in a specific neighborhood or the spread of COVID19 in a particular region are examples of regression problems.

Unsupervised Learning

Unsupervised learning algorithms uncover insights and relationships in unlabeled data. In this case, models are fed input data but the desired outcomes are unknown, so they have to make inferences based on circumstantial evidence, without any guidance or training. The models are not trained with the “right answer,” so they must find patterns on their own.

One of the most common types of unsupervised learning is clustering, which consists of grouping similar data. This method is mostly used for exploratory analysis and can help you detect hidden patterns or trends.

For example, the marketing team of an e-commerce company could use clustering to improve customer segmentation. Given a set of income and spending data, a machine learning model can identify groups of customers with similar behaviors.

Segmentation allows marketers to tailor strategies for each key market. They might offer promotions and discounts for low-income customers that are high spenders on the site, as a way to reward loyalty and improve retention.

Semi-Supervised Learning

In semi-supervised learning, training data is split into two. A small amount of labeled data and a larger set of unlabeled data.

In this case, the model uses labeled data as an input to make inferences about the unlabeled data, providing more accurate results than regular supervised-learning models.

This approach is gaining popularity, especially for tasks involving large datasets such as image classification. Semi-supervised learning doesn’t require a large number of labeled data, so it’s faster to set up, more cost-effective than supervised learning methods, and ideal for businesses that receive huge amounts of data.

Reinforcement Learning

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how a software agent (or computer program) ought to act in a situation to maximize the reward. In short, reinforced machine learning models attempt to determine the best possible path they should take in a given situation. They do this through trial and error. Since there is no training data, machines learn from their own mistakes and choose the actions that lead to the best solution or maximum reward.

This machine learning method is mostly used in robotics and gaming. Video games demonstrate a clear relationship between actions and results, and can measure success by keeping score. Therefore, they’re a great way to improve reinforcement learning algorithms.

Deep Learning (DL)

Deep learning models can be supervised, semi-supervised, or unsupervised (or a combination of any or all of the three). They’re advanced machine learning algorithms used by tech giants, like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon to run entire systems and power things, like self driving cars and smart assistants.

Deep learning is based on Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), a type of computer system that emulates the way the human brain works. Deep learning algorithms or neural networks are built with multiple layers of interconnected neurons, allowing multiple systems to work together simultaneously, and step-by-step.

When a model receives input data ‒ which could be image, text, video, or audio ‒ and is asked to perform a task (for example, text classification with machine learning), the data passes through every layer, enabling the model to learn progressively. It’s kind of like a human brain that evolves with age and experience!

Deep learning is common in image recognition, speech recognition, and Natural Language Processing (NLP). Deep learning models usually perform better than other machine learning algorithms for complex problems and massive sets of data. However, they generally require millions upon millions of pieces of training data, so it takes quite a lot of time to train them.

How Machine Learning Works

In order to understand how machine learning works, first you need to know what a “tag” is. To train image recognition, for example, you would “tag” photos of dogs, cats, horses, etc., with the appropriate animal name. This is also called data labeling.

When working with machine learning text analysis, you would feed a text analysis model with text training data, then tag it, depending on what kind of analysis you’re doing. If you’re working with sentiment analysis, you would feed the model with customer feedback, for example, and train the model by tagging each comment as Positive, Neutral, and Negative.

Take a look at the diagram below:

At its most simplistic, the machine learning process involves three steps:

  1. Feed a machine learning model training input data. In our case, this could be customer comments from social media or customer service data.

  2. Tag training data with a desired output. In this case, tell your sentiment analysis model whether each comment or piece of data is Positive, Neutral, or Negative. The model transforms the training data into text vectors – numbers that represent data features.

  3. Test your model by feeding it testing (or unseen) data. Algorithms are trained to associate feature vectors with tags based on manually tagged samples, then learn to make predictions when processing unseen data.

If your new model performs to your standards and criteria after testing it, it’s ready to be put to work on all kinds of new data. If it’s not performing accurately, you’ll need to keep training. Furthermore, as human language and industry-specific language morphs and changes, you may need to continually train your model with new information.

Machine Learning Use Cases

Machine learning applications and use cases are nearly endless, especially as we begin to work from home more (or have hybrid offices), become more tied to our smartphones, and use machine learning-guided technology to get around.

Machine learning in finance, healthcare, hospitality, government, and beyond, is already in regular use. Businesses are beginning to see the benefits of using machine learning tools to improve their processes, gain valuable insights from unstructured data, and automate tasks that would otherwise require hours of tedious, manual work (which usually produces much less accurate results).

For example, UberEats uses machine learning to estimate optimum times for drivers to pick up food orders, while Spotify leverages machine learning to offer personalized content and personalized marketing. And Dell uses machine learning text analysis to save hundreds of hours analyzing thousands of employee surveys to listen to the voice of employee (VoE) and improve employee satisfaction.

How do you think Google Maps predicts peaks in traffic and Netflix creates personalized movie recommendations, even informs the creation of new content ? By using machine learning, of course.

There are many different applications of machine learning, which can benefit your business in countless ways. You’ll just need to define a strategy to help you decide the best way to implement machine learning into your existing processes. In the meantime, here are some common machine learning use cases and applications that might spark some ideas:

  • Social Media Monitoring

  • Customer Service & Customer Satisfaction

  • Image Recognition

  • Virtual Assistants

  • Product Recommendations

  • Stock Market Trading

  • Medical Diagnosis

Social Media Monitoring

Using machine learning you can monitor mentions of your brand on social media and immediately identify if customers require urgent attention. By detecting mentions from angry customers, in real-time, you can automatically tag customer feedback and respond right away. You might also want to analyze customer support interactions on social media and gauge customer satisfaction (CSAT), to see how well your team is performing.

Natural Language Processing gives machines the ability to break down spoken or written language much like a human would, to process “natural” language, so machine learning can handle text from practically any source.

Customer Service & Customer Satisfaction

Machine learning allows you to integrate powerful text analysis tools with customer support tools, so you can analyze your emails, live chats, and all manner of internal data on the go. You can use machine learning to tag support tickets and route them to the correct teams or auto-respond to common queries so you never leave a customer in the cold.

Furthermore, using machine learning to set up a voice of customer (VoC) program and a customer feedback loop will ensure that you follow the customer journey from start to finish to improve the customer experience (CX), decrease customer churn, and, ultimately, increase your profits.

Image Recognition

Image recognition is helping companies identify and classify images. For example, facial recognition technology is being used as a form of identification, from unlocking phones to making payments.

Self-driving cars also use image recognition to perceive space and obstacles. For example, they can learn to recognize stop signs, identify intersections, and make decisions based on what they see.

Virtual Assistants

Virtual assistants, like Siri, Alexa, Google Now, all make use of machine learning to automatically process and answer voice requests. They quickly scan information, remember related queries, learn from previous interactions, and send commands to other apps, so they can collect information and deliver the most effective answer.

Customer support teams are already using virtual assistants to handle phone calls, automatically route support tickets, to the correct teams, and speed up interactions with customers via computer-generated responses.

Product Recommendations

Association rule-learning is a machine learning technique that can be used to analyze purchasing habits at the supermarket or on e-commerce sites. It works by searching for relationships between variables and finding common associations in transactions (products that consumers usually buy together). This data is then used for product placement strategies and similar product recommendations.

Associated rules can also be useful to plan a marketing campaign or analyze web usage.

Stock Market Trading

Machine learning algorithms can be trained to identify trading opportunities, by recognizing patterns and behaviors in historical data. Humans are often driven by emotions when it comes to making investments, so sentiment analysis with machine learning can play a huge role in identifying good and bad investing opportunities, with no human bias, whatsoever. They can even save time and allow traders more time away from their screens by automating tasks.

Medical Diagnosis

The ability of machines to find patterns in complex data is shaping the present and future. Take machine learning initiatives during the COVID-19 outbreak, for instance. AI tools have helped predict how the virus will spread over time, and shaped how we control it. It’s also helped diagnose patients by analyzing lung CTs and detecting fevers using facial recognition, and identified patients at a higher risk of developing serious respiratory disease.

Machine learning is driving innovation in many fields, and every day we’re seeing new interesting use cases emerge. In business, the overall benefits of machine learning include:

  • It’s cost-effective and scalable. You only need to train a machine learning model once, and you can scale up or down depending on how much data you receive.

  • Performs more accurately than humans. Machine learning models are trained with a certain amount of labeled data and will use it to make predictions on unseen data. Based on this data, machines define a set of rules that they apply to all datasets, helping them provide consistent and accurate results. No need to worry about human error or innate bias. And you can train the tools to the needs and criteria of your business.

  • Works in real-time, 24/7. Machine learning models can automatically analyze data in real-time, allowing you to immediately detect negative opinions or urgent tickets and take action.

Get Started With Machine Learning Tools

When you’re ready to get started with machine learning tools it comes down to the Build vs. Buy Debate. If you have a data science and computer engineering background or are prepared to hire whole teams of coders and computer scientists, building your own with open-source libraries can produce great results. Building your own tools, however, can take months or years and cost in the tens of thousands.

Using SaaS or MLaaS (Machine Learning as a Service) tools, on the other hand, is much cheaper because you only pay what you use. They can also be implemented right away and new platforms and techniques make SaaS tools just as powerful, scalable, customizable, and accurate as building your own.

Whether you choose to build or buy you machine learning tools, here are some of the best of each:

This allows you to see which aspects of your business are particularly positive and which are negative.

Other techniques, like intent classification are especially useful for incoming emails or social media inquiries to automatically show why the customer is writing. Also, at the bottom right you can see word clouds that show the most used and most important words and phrases by sentiment.

MonkeyLearn pricing.

They specialize in industries, like aerospace, automotive, energy, entertainment, financial services, food, healthcare, IoT, pharmaceutical, transportation, telecommunications, and more, so many of their tools are ready to go, right out of the box.

You can use pre-trained models or train your own with classification and regression and time series forecasting.

body_markdown:
The purpose of this article is to highlight how SE's can approach the specific use-case of **Ticket Deflection - Support Engineering Teams -** effectively through Stack Overflow for Teams (SO4T) to **drive faster MTTR & support self-service (deflection)**. The information below will discuss the importance of:

1. Uncovering and identifying the support team pains

2. Driving the value of where SO4T can fill in that gap with a solution to address the specific pain and

3. What is the outcome of the call to align on next steps

**Common Pains:**

- A large amount of tickets are duplicates

- Members of the team spend increasingly large amounts of time handling tickets versus other work

- No easy way to communicate with other teams to answer difficult questions, resulting in a longer time to resolution (more resources involved, expensive answer)

- Lacking a place where answers can be documented for future self-service 

- Service centers are a cost center, escalations are pricey 


- 

**Discovery Questions - identify pain:** 

- Can you walk me through your support process? 

  - What are the channels? (Chat, ServiceNow)

- What types of tickets are being managed? 

- What knowledge areas? 

- What could those supporting tickets be working on instead? 

**Discovery Questions - identify initiative:**

- What are the named projects and/or initiatives that align to improved ticket escalations, MTTR etc?

- Who owns this project/pain today?

- Is there any budget or allocated resource(s) to \____\_ project?

- What's the timeline in place to address the current gaps today?

**Outcome** after initial discovery and/or demonstration:

- Understand tech-stack: ChatOps, Documentation, Code Repo, ticketing system, etc.

- Grasp the specific workflow associated with ticket deflection at (customer X)

- Primary pain that's (hopefully) quantified

  - Force ranked each named initiative

  - Who owns the pain/initiative

**Assets** you can reference some example Q&A/articles to highlight this flow for demo purposes are below. Also available in the "collection name" collection[ here.](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/collections/18334)

title: Best Practices for New Support Engineering Team Member
body:
The purpose of this article is to highlight how SE's can approach the specific use-case of Ticket Deflection - Support Engineering Teams - effectively through Stack Overflow for Teams (SO4T) to drive faster MTTR & support self-service (deflection). The information below will discuss the importance of:

  1. Uncovering and identifying the support team pains

  2. Driving the value of where SO4T can fill in that gap with a solution to address the specific pain and

  3. What is the outcome of the call to align on next steps

Common Pains:

  • A large amount of tickets are duplicates

  • Members of the team spend increasingly large amounts of time handling tickets versus other work

  • No easy way to communicate with other teams to answer difficult questions, resulting in a longer time to resolution (more resources involved, expensive answer)

  • Lacking a place where answers can be documented for future self-service 

  • Service centers are a cost center, escalations are pricey 

Discovery Questions - identify pain: 

  • Can you walk me through your support process? 

    • What are the channels? (Chat, ServiceNow)

  • What types of tickets are being managed? 

  • What knowledge areas? 

  • What could those supporting tickets be working on instead? 

Discovery Questions - identify initiative:

  • What are the named projects and/or initiatives that align to improved ticket escalations, MTTR etc?

  • Who owns this project/pain today?

  • Is there any budget or allocated resource(s) to _____ project?

  • What's the timeline in place to address the current gaps today?

Outcome after initial discovery and/or demonstration:

  • Understand tech-stack: ChatOps, Documentation, Code Repo, ticketing system, etc.

  • Grasp the specific workflow associated with ticket deflection at (customer X)

  • Primary pain that's (hopefully) quantified

    • Force ranked each named initiative

    • Who owns the pain/initiative

Assets you can reference some example Q&A/articles to highlight this flow for demo purposes are below. Also available in the "collection name" collection here.

body_markdown:
The purpose of this article is to highlight how SE's can approach the specific use-case of disseminating information effectively through Stack Overflow for Teams (SO4T) to **drive innovation**. The information below will discuss the importance of:

1. Uncovering and identifying the developer pain associated with driving innovation

2. Driving the value of where SO4T can fill in that gap with a solution to address the specific pain and

3. Outcomes from tailored demo/discovery

**Common Pains To Identify**

- Massive amounts of time is spent by SMEs answering duplicative Q&A in ChatOps (not retained knowledge or re-usable/discoverable)
- No easy way to communicate with other teams to answer difficult questions, resulting in a longer wait time (more resources involved, expensive answer)
- Lacking a place where answers can be documented for future self-service (with validated trust built-in via comment, upvotes, etc.)

**Questions**

- Identify initiatives/projects

  - What are the named projects and/or initiatives that align to improved developer productivity?

  - Who owns this project/pain today?

  - Is there any budget or allocated resource(s) to \____\_ project?

  - Is there a timeline in place to address the current gaps/challenges today?

- Questions to driver numbers:

  - How do others gain this knowledge?

  - Are these people being pulled into a lot of things at once? How does that impact their own work? What would happen if they left?

  - Does everyone have access to the applications? What if someone doesn't?

  - Are you able to easily find information across these?

  - Do you find that information currently documented is reliable?

  - Are your SMEs adding new information in current repo's that team members can access?

- Questions that drive towards value:

  - Where would you say the most valuable information about your company is stored?

  - What do you see as the impact of having the most valuable information stored in peoples heads?

  - Walk me through the knowledge application landscape. What does a search path look like?

  - How valuable is it for everyone to have access to all knowledge?

**Value**

- Depending on the answers provided to the above questions, focus on where we can align to:

  1. **Developer productivity**

  2. **Accelerated innovation**

  3. **Improved up-skilling & onboarding**

**Outcomes** after initial discovery and/or demonstration:

- Tech-stack: ChatOps, Documentation, Code Repo, ticketing system, etc.

- Grasp the specific workflow associated with developer productivity (i.e. current inefficiencies)

- Primary pain that's (hopefully) quantified

  - Force ranked each named initiative
  - Who owns the pain/initiative

**Assets** you can reference some example Q&A/articles to highlight this flow for demo purposes are below. Also available in the "Community of Practice" collection [here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/collections/18324)

1. Front-line IC: [Can Cloud 1.0 talk to Cloud 2.0?](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/18197/18326#18326)

2. Manager: [What are some publicly available datasets that others have found to be useful?](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/155)

3. Director/VP: [A Comprehensive Guide to SAP S/4HANA Migration](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18084)

\**As a request, if you build custom-demo assets that **could be** more broadly utilized, feel free to add it to the "Community of Practice" collection here within the SOE Demo instance.*

[Activate Office](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18159#heading-activate-office)

# Redeem a product key or activate Office.

If you just bought or got a Microsoft 365 subscription or a non-subscription version of Office, such as Office 2021, there could be some things you need to do before you install or activate the Office apps.

Select your options from below:

## Redeem a product key and install the apps

If you just bought Office and have a physical package, the first thing to do is redeem the product key included with the packaging.

Or, if you bought Office through an online retailer, you may have received the product key via email, or it's written on your receipt.

To redeem this key, go to [setup.office.com](https://setup.office.com/) and sign in with an existing Microsoft account or create a new one.

You only need to redeem this key once.

[Learn more](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/get-help-with-setup-office-com-6e1bc8e8-9e8e-4cce-8b9d-80dcbe17f253)

![Shows the location of the product key in the product box and on the product key card.](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/e3a275ae-61d3-4841-b841-da01421d28ad.png)

![Shows the buttons for signing in or creating a new account.](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/57c70dc7-134f-4f3b-8bbd-1c00d2f53352.png)

## Activate Office

![Shows the "Sign in to set up Office" page that might appear after you install Office](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/dcc564ff-7829-4927-9870-ccfc518da624.png)

If you've already redeemed a product key and Office is installed, the next step is to launch an Office app and follow the prompts to activate it.

[Learn more](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/activate-office-5bd38f38-db92-448b-a982-ad170b1e187e)

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/87731549-2e21-4474-af52-e12daed75102.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/87731549-2e21-4474-af52-e12daed75102.png)

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/b522a159-2fc3-4183-a0ae-e66d8a5ded32.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/b522a159-2fc3-4183-a0ae-e66d8a5ded32.png)

### **I’m an SME: What’s in it for me?**

Each of you has a wealth of information at your fingertips that you have the opportunity to share with your colleagues. As you get started with your new responsibilities, you may be wondering, “What’s in it for me?”

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/cae1fa0c-6a5b-4e79-a89f-feeba15aa14f.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/cae1fa0c-6a5b-4e79-a89f-feeba15aa14f.png)**Time Saved:** Stack Overflow for Teams keeps you from having to answer repeat questions time and again, so you’ll have additional time to focus on other productive tasks

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/c549c59a-50cc-4a97-bf5f-ae6eb0e94605.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/c549c59a-50cc-4a97-bf5f-ae6eb0e94605.png)**Credibility:** By answering questions, writing articles, and sharing your knowledge, you’ll earn reputation points and badges to gain clout amongst your colleagues

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/b5132521-ef0d-446d-9eda-6678f61355b6.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/b5132521-ef0d-446d-9eda-6678f61355b6.png)**Quantifiable Effort:** Begin to track your contributions, reputation points, and user-moderation to tie your participation in Stack Overflow for Teams to your personal KPIs and goals

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/31065b32-9d06-4413-953d-8d1ff17587cc.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/31065b32-9d06-4413-953d-8d1ff17587cc.png)**Cross-functional Collaboration and Knowledge Sharing:** Your participation in Stack Overflow for Teams will allow you to communicate with, educate, and learn from peers across your org - Including people you may not have otherwise collaborated with
title: SME: What's in it for me?
body:
I’m an SME: What’s in it for me?

Each of you has a wealth of information at your fingertips that you have the opportunity to share with your colleagues. As you get started with your new responsibilities, you may be wondering, “What’s in it for me?”

Time Saved: Stack Overflow for Teams keeps you from having to answer repeat questions time and again, so you’ll have additional time to focus on other productive tasks

Credibility: By answering questions, writing articles, and sharing your knowledge, you’ll earn reputation points and badges to gain clout amongst your colleagues

Quantifiable Effort: Begin to track your contributions, reputation points, and user-moderation to tie your participation in Stack Overflow for Teams to your personal KPIs and goals

Cross-functional Collaboration and Knowledge Sharing: Your participation in Stack Overflow for Teams will allow you to communicate with, educate, and learn from peers across your org - Including people you may not have otherwise collaborated with

# [![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/7b093819-7da8-4eca-ae3a-84b67dbc4526.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/7b093819-7da8-4eca-ae3a-84b67dbc4526.png)

1. [Why are we here?](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18053#heading-why-are-we-here)

2. [Role overview](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18053#heading-role-overview)

3. [Pre-launch expectations](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18053#heading-pre-launch-expectations)

4. [How to ask & answer a question](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18053#heading-how-to-ask-answer-a-question)

5. [DEMO](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions)

6. [Next steps](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/18053#heading-next-steps)

# Why are we here?

Your company's specific value drivers:

![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/06c697b8-f460-4bc4-9c2d-ae863f023c99.png)[Attract, Onboard, & Retain Talent](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/q/18061/28269)

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/f4fa6098-bfb8-4d56-9c17-9854d01a9aa2.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/f4fa6098-bfb8-4d56-9c17-9854d01a9aa2.png)[Improve Productivity & Collaboration](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/18063)

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/1d26dc19-b98a-486b-bf6d-24a964b2c332.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/1d26dc19-b98a-486b-bf6d-24a964b2c332.png)[Accelerate Technology Transformation & Initiatives](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/18065)

# Role overview

### [![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/0d683f25-07f9-42de-a3a0-eead0e98ea89.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/0d683f25-07f9-42de-a3a0-eead0e98ea89.png)What is a Subject Matter Expert?

The folks who hold expertise in a given knowledge area, and are responsible for efficiently sharing knowledge in a robust manner.

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/8642b3d5-e55a-49ad-86e3-886bded88537.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/8642b3d5-e55a-49ad-86e3-886bded88537.png)

### 

### [![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/eac3b5b7-4280-42d4-8d4f-11d9df016aea.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/eac3b5b7-4280-42d4-8d4f-11d9df016aea.png)Your role as an SME

A Subject Matter Expert (SME) is a **vital role** within the Stack Overflow for Teams community. SMEs are the users within the platform who have expertise in a specific knowledge domain, such as developer languages, tools, projects and products.

As an SME, your role in launching Teams for your organization is seeding content for your colleagues.

- Effectively using and creating tags on content for easy searching

- Adding frequently asked questions and answers

- Transporting project docs, announcements, and how-to’s

# Pre-launch expectations

### The pre-launch checklist for the SME

Ahead of launch, your leadership needs help populating content to make for a welcoming team experience.

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/ca419d19-2eea-4008-b853-d61686c315f1.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/ca419d19-2eea-4008-b853-d61686c315f1.png)

# How to ask & answer a question

### [How to ask a high quality question?](https://stackoverflow.com/help/how-to-ask)

1. Summarize the problem as a title. Keep it interesting and limit it to one sentence.

2. Start the title with the 5 W’s: Who, What, Where, When, Why (How).

3. In the body of the question fully explain the problem. Including how you encountered the problem and difficulties you ran into along the way. Use formatting like bullets or lists to help you organize your question.

4. Proofread before posting. Check to make sure you didn’t miss anything.

**For more tips check out the [Stack Overflow Resource Center](https://stackoverflowsolutions.com/teams/best-practices)**

### How to answer a question

1. Read the question carefully. Make sure your answer fully addresses the question being asked. If it doesn’t, be sure to point that out in your answer.

2. Provide context for links. Users should be able to understand the solution before clicking a link.

3. Write to the best of your ability. Proofread your answer and remember that you can come back and edit the answer later if you’d like.

# Next steps

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/4742dace-7d03-4b40-84ee-05718e8af847.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/4742dace-7d03-4b40-84ee-05718e8af847.png)

body_markdown:
Amazon Web Services (AWS), a subsidiary of Amazon.com, Inc., is a robust, on-demand cloud computing platform that provides a mix of infrastructure as a service (IaaS), platform as a service (PaaS), and packaged software as a service (SaaS) offerings. Launched in 2006, AWS offers over 200 services and has since grown into the most comprehensive, widely adopted, and broadly distributed cloud platform across the globe.

The Services

AWS offers a vast array of services designed to suit a multitude of business needs. These include computing power, storage options, networking, databases, migration, management tools, security features, application integration, analytics, and much more.

Notable services include Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud), which provides scalable computing capacity in the cloud, and Amazon S3 (Simple Storage Service), an object storage service offering industry-leading scalability, data availability, security, and performance.

Other noteworthy services include Amazon RDS for relational databases, AWS Lambda for running serverless applications, Amazon DynamoDB for NoSQL databases, Amazon CloudFront for content delivery, and Amazon Redshift for data warehousing. AWS also offers services tailored to specific industries such as AWS Health for the healthcare industry and AWS RoboMaker for robotics.

Scalability and Flexibility

One of the key benefits of AWS is its scalability and flexibility. Businesses can quickly spin up resources as they need them, deploying hundreds or even thousands of servers in minutes. This means they have the freedom to experiment and innovate, reducing the time it takes to bring ideas to fruition. Plus, with the 'pay-as-you-go' pricing model, businesses only pay for the services they use, which leads to significant cost savings.

Security and Compliance

Security on AWS is a top priority, and the platform is built to meet the requirements of the most security-sensitive organizations. It provides several security capabilities and services to increase privacy and control network access, including network firewalls and encryption in transit. AWS infrastructure is compliant with industry standards like GDPR, HIPAA, and PCI DSS, making it a trustworthy choice for organizations across sectors.
title: What is AWS?
body:
Amazon Web Services (AWS), a subsidiary of Amazon.com, Inc., is a robust, on-demand cloud computing platform that provides a mix of infrastructure as a service (IaaS), platform as a service (PaaS), and packaged software as a service (SaaS) offerings. Launched in 2006, AWS offers over 200 services and has since grown into the most comprehensive, widely adopted, and broadly distributed cloud platform across the globe.

The Services

AWS offers a vast array of services designed to suit a multitude of business needs. These include computing power, storage options, networking, databases, migration, management tools, security features, application integration, analytics, and much more.

Notable services include Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud), which provides scalable computing capacity in the cloud, and Amazon S3 (Simple Storage Service), an object storage service offering industry-leading scalability, data availability, security, and performance.

Other noteworthy services include Amazon RDS for relational databases, AWS Lambda for running serverless applications, Amazon DynamoDB for NoSQL databases, Amazon CloudFront for content delivery, and Amazon Redshift for data warehousing. AWS also offers services tailored to specific industries such as AWS Health for the healthcare industry and AWS RoboMaker for robotics.

Scalability and Flexibility

One of the key benefits of AWS is its scalability and flexibility. Businesses can quickly spin up resources as they need them, deploying hundreds or even thousands of servers in minutes. This means they have the freedom to experiment and innovate, reducing the time it takes to bring ideas to fruition. Plus, with the 'pay-as-you-go' pricing model, businesses only pay for the services they use, which leads to significant cost savings.

Security and Compliance

Security on AWS is a top priority, and the platform is built to meet the requirements of the most security-sensitive organizations. It provides several security capabilities and services to increase privacy and control network access, including network firewalls and encryption in transit. AWS infrastructure is compliant with industry standards like GDPR, HIPAA, and PCI DSS, making it a trustworthy choice for organizations across sectors.
