# 7. Optional in Java and anti-patterns using it by [Mervyn McCreight](https://medium.com/u/9da1de78f811?source=post_page-----7648edd18a22--------------------------------)

Optional was introduced in [Java 8](https://medium.freecodecamp.org/these-are-the-best-free-courses-to-help-you-learn-java-8-and-java-9-a7615c8644ab) to reduce the risk of [NullPointerException ](https://javarevisited.blogspot.com/2013/05/ava-tips-and-best-practices-to-avoid-nullpointerexception-program-application.html)and improve the readability of code by showing the intention better but the bigger problem was that it wasn’t clear [how to use Optional in the right way](https://javarevisited.blogspot.com/2017/04/10-examples-of-optional-in-java-8.html) so most developers started using in the same way they do the NULL check, which means still similar code.

If you are also on the same boat, do read this article to find out ***how NOT to use Optional in Java***.

## Optional in Java and anti-patterns using it

### by Mervyn McCreight and Mehmet Emin Tok

#### medium.com

# 8. Microservices with Spring Boot and Spring Cloud. From config server to OAuth2 server (without inMemory things) — Part 1 by [Marcus Hert Da Corégio](https://medium.com/u/5cfb26e8714b?source=post_page-----7648edd18a22--------------------------------)

### Introduction

# 9. Microservices with Spring Boot and Spring Cloud. From config server to OAuth2 server (without inMemory things) — Part 2 by [Marcus Hert Da Corégio](https://medium.com/u/5cfb26e8714b?source=post_page-----7648edd18a22--------------------------------)

This is the second part of the above article which covers how to build the auth service

## Microservices with Spring Boot and Spring Cloud.

### Introduction

One of the better course on this topic.

### Do you want to Learn to Build Amazing REST API with Spring Boot? Do you want to learn what the Hype about Microservices…

That’s all guys, these are some of the best articles I found on [Medium](https://medium.com/u/504c7870fdb6?source=post_page-----7648edd18a22--------------------------------) this week for Java developers. If you like my curation, I may continue this kind of articles in the future.

body_markdown:
Standard deviation is a number that describes how spread out the values are.

A low standard deviation means that most of the numbers are close to the mean (average) value.

A high standard deviation means that the values are spread out over a wider range.

Example: This time we have registered the speed of 7 cars:

`speed = [86,87,88,86,87,85,86]`

The standard deviation is:

`0.9`

Meaning that most of the values are within the range of 0.9 from the mean value, which is 86.4.

Let us do the same with a selection of numbers with a wider range:

`speed = [32,111,138,28,59,77,97]`

The standard deviation is:

`37.85`

Meaning that most of the values are within the range of 37.85 from the mean value, which is 77.4.

As you can see, a higher standard deviation indicates that the values are spread out over a wider range.

The NumPy module has a method to calculate the standard deviation:

### Example

Use the NumPy `std()` method to find the standard deviation:

```
import numpy
speed = [86,87,88,86,87,85,86]
x = numpy.std(speed)
print(x)
```

### 

---

## Variance

Variance is another number that indicates how spread out the values are.

In fact, if you take the square root of the variance, you get the standard deviation!

Or the other way around, if you multiply the standard deviation by itself, you get the variance!

To calculate the variance you have to do as follows:

1\. Find the mean:

`(32+111+138+28+59+77+97) / 7 = 77.4`

2\. For each value: find the difference from the mean:

` 32 - 77.4 = -45.4`  
`111 - 77.4 =  33.6`  
`138 - 77.4 =  60.6`  
` 28 - 77.4 = -49.4`  
` 59 - 77.4 = -18.4`  
` 77 - 77.4 = - 0.4`  
` 97 - 77.4 =  19.6`

3\. For each difference: find the square value:

`(-45.4)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` = 2061.16`  
` (33.6)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` = 1128.96`  
` (60.6)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` = 3672.36`  
`(-49.4)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` = 2440.36`  
`(-18.4)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` =  338.56`  
`(- 0.4)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` =    0.16`  
` (19.6)`\<sup\>`2`\</sup\>` =  384.16`

4\. The variance is the average number of these squared differences:

`(2061.16+1128.96+3672.36+2440.36+338.56+0.16+384.16) / 7 = 1432.2`

Luckily, NumPy has a method to calculate the variance:

### Example

Use the NumPy `var()` method to find the variance:

import numpy

speed = \[32,111,138,28,59,77,97\]

x = numpy.var(speed)

print(x)

---

## Standard Deviation

As we have learned, the formula to find the standard deviation is the square root of the variance:

√`1432.25 = 37.85`

Or, as in the example from before, use the NumPy to calculate the standard deviation:

### Example

Use the NumPy `std()` method to find the standard deviation:

import numpy

speed = \[32,111,138,28,59,77,97\]

x = numpy.std(speed)

print(x)

Try it Yourself »

---

## Symbols

Standard Deviation is often represented by the symbol Sigma: σ

Variance is often represented by the symbol Sigma Square: σ\<sup\>2\</sup\>

----------

**FAQ**

[Why Is Overfitting Bad in Machine Learning?](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/61) 

[The cross-entropy error function in neural networks](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/9302)
title: Machine Learning - Standard Deviation
body:
Standard deviation is a number that describes how spread out the values are.

A low standard deviation means that most of the numbers are close to the mean (average) value.

A high standard deviation means that the values are spread out over a wider range.

Example: This time we have registered the speed of 7 cars:

speed = [86,87,88,86,87,85,86]

The standard deviation is:

0.9

Meaning that most of the values are within the range of 0.9 from the mean value, which is 86.4.

Let us do the same with a selection of numbers with a wider range:

speed = [32,111,138,28,59,77,97]

The standard deviation is:

37.85

Meaning that most of the values are within the range of 37.85 from the mean value, which is 77.4.

As you can see, a higher standard deviation indicates that the values are spread out over a wider range.

The NumPy module has a method to calculate the standard deviation:

Example

Use the NumPy std() method to find the standard deviation:

import numpy
speed = [86,87,88,86,87,85,86]
x = numpy.std(speed)
print(x)

Variance

Variance is another number that indicates how spread out the values are.

In fact, if you take the square root of the variance, you get the standard deviation!

Or the other way around, if you multiply the standard deviation by itself, you get the variance!

To calculate the variance you have to do as follows:

1. Find the mean:

(32+111+138+28+59+77+97) / 7 = 77.4

2. For each value: find the difference from the mean:

 32 - 77.4 = -45.4
111 - 77.4 =  33.6
138 - 77.4 =  60.6
 28 - 77.4 = -49.4
 59 - 77.4 = -18.4
 77 - 77.4 = - 0.4
 97 - 77.4 =  19.6

3. For each difference: find the square value:

(-45.4)<sup>2</sup> = 2061.16
 (33.6)<sup>2</sup> = 1128.96
 (60.6)<sup>2</sup> = 3672.36
(-49.4)<sup>2</sup> = 2440.36
(-18.4)<sup>2</sup> =  338.56
(- 0.4)<sup>2</sup> =    0.16
 (19.6)<sup>2</sup> =  384.16

4. The variance is the average number of these squared differences:

(2061.16+1128.96+3672.36+2440.36+338.56+0.16+384.16) / 7 = 1432.2

Luckily, NumPy has a method to calculate the variance:

Example

Use the NumPy var() method to find the variance:

import numpy

speed = [32,111,138,28,59,77,97]

x = numpy.var(speed)

print(x)

Standard Deviation

As we have learned, the formula to find the standard deviation is the square root of the variance:

√1432.25 = 37.85

Or, as in the example from before, use the NumPy to calculate the standard deviation:

Example

Use the NumPy std() method to find the standard deviation:

import numpy

speed = [32,111,138,28,59,77,97]

x = numpy.std(speed)

print(x)

Try it Yourself »

Symbols

Standard Deviation is often represented by the symbol Sigma: σ

Variance is often represented by the symbol Sigma Square: σ<sup>2</sup>

FAQ

Why Is Overfitting Bad in Machine Learning?

The cross-entropy error function in neural networks

body_markdown:
# **Sign in and install Microsoft 365 or Office for Mac.**

1. Go to [www.office.com](https://www.office.com/) and if you're not already signed in, select **Sign in**.

   **Note:** If you're using Microsoft 365 operated by 21 Vianet, sign in with your work or school account to [login.partner.microsoftonline.cn](https://login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/).

   If you're using Microsoft 365 Germany, sign in with your work or school account to [portal.office.de](https://portal.office.de/).

2. Sign in with the account you associated with this version of Microsoft 365 or Office. This account can be a Microsoft account, or work or school account. [I forgot the account I use with Office](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/i-forgot-the-username-or-password-for-the-account-i-use-with-microsoft-365-eba0b4a2-c0ae-472c-99f6-bc63ee2425a8?wt.mc_id=SCL_InstallOffice_Home#)

3. After signing in, follow the steps that match the type of account you signed in with.

   **You signed in with a Microsoft account**  
   ![Line](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/ee907d18-39a7-437c-9852-073694f74c84.png)

   - From the Microsoft 365 home page select **Install Office** to start the download.

     ![Screenshot of Office.com home page after signing in](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/9e279f97-5f46-4727-9bd5-e4f5d2699315.png)

   **You signed in with a work or school account**  
   ![Line](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/ee907d18-39a7-437c-9852-073694f74c84.png)

   1. From the Microsoft 365 home page select **Install Office** (if you set a different start page, go to [aka.ms/office-install](https://aka.ms/office-install)).

      **Notes:**

      - For Microsoft 365 operated by 21 Vianet go to [login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/account](https://login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/account).

      - For Microsoft 365 Germany go to [portal.office.de/account](https://portal.office.de/account).

      ![Screenshot of Office.com if signing in with a work or school account](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/4d96bcbc-ed1b-41a7-a365-f71a41cab2bb.png)

   2. Select **Office 365 apps** to begin the download.

   **Note:**  **Don't see an install option after signing in?** There could be an issue with your account. Select [Need help?](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/download-and-install-or-reinstall-microsoft-365-or-office-2021-on-a-pc-or-mac-4414eaaf-0478-48be-9c42-23adc4716658#installsteps=need_help) from above and review the issues listed in the section **Account questions**.

4. Follow the instructions below to complete installing your Microsoft 365 apps.

# **Sign in and install Microsoft 365 or Office for PC**

### Sign in to download Microsoft 365 or Office

1. Go to [www.office.com](https://www.office.com/) and if you're not already signed in, select **Sign in**.

   **Note:** If you're using Microsoft 365 operated by 21 Vianet, sign in with your work or school account to [login.partner.microsoftonline.cn](https://login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/).

   If you're using Microsoft 365 Germany, sign in with your work or school account to [portal.office.de](https://portal.office.de/).

2. Sign in with the account you associated with this version of Microsoft 365. This account can be a Microsoft account, or work or school account. [I forgot the account I use with Office](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/i-forgot-the-username-or-password-for-the-account-i-use-with-microsoft-365-eba0b4a2-c0ae-472c-99f6-bc63ee2425a8?wt.mc_id=SCL_InstallOffice_Home#)

3. After signing in, follow the steps that match the type of account you signed in with.

   **You signed in with a Microsoft account**  
   ![Line](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/ee907d18-39a7-437c-9852-073694f74c84.png)

   1. From the Microsoft 365 home page select **Install apps**.

      ![Screenshot of Office.com home page after signing in](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/9e279f97-5f46-4727-9bd5-e4f5d2699315.png)

   2. Select **Install** (or depending on your version, **Install apps\>**).

   **You signed in with a work or school account**  
   ![Line](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/ee907d18-39a7-437c-9852-073694f74c84.png)

   1. From the home page select **Install apps** (If you set a different start page, go to [aka.ms/office-install](https://aka.ms/office-install).)

      **Notes:**

      - For Microsoft 365 operated by 21 Vianet go to [login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/account](https://login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/account).

      - For Microsoft 365 Germany go to [portal.office.de/account](https://portal.office.de/account).

      ![Screenshot of Office.com if signing in with a work or school account](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/4d96bcbc-ed1b-41a7-a365-f71a41cab2bb.png)

   2. Select **Microsoft 365 apps** to begin the installation.

   The 64-bit version is installed by default unless Microsoft 365 or Office detects you already have a 32-bit version of Microsoft 365 or Office (or a stand-alone app such as Project or Visio) installed. In this case, the 32-bit version of Microsoft 365 or Office will be installed instead.

   To change from a [32-bit version to a 64-bit version](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/choose-between-the-64-bit-or-32-bit-version-of-office-2dee7807-8f95-4d0c-b5fe-6c6f49b8d261?wt.mc_id=SCL_InstallOffice_Home#) or vice versa, you need to [uninstall](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/uninstall-office-from-a-pc-9dd49b83-264a-477a-8fcc-2fdf5dbf61d8) Microsoft 365 first (including any stand-alone Microsoft 365 apps you have such as Project of Visio). Once the uninstall is complete, sign in again to [www.office.com](https://www.office.com/) and select **Other install options**, choose the language and version you want (64 or 32-bit), and then select **Install**. (See [Install Visio](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/install-visio-or-access-visio-for-the-web-f98f21e3-aa02-4827-9167-ddab5b025710) or [Install Project](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/install-project-7059249b-d9fe-4d61-ab96-5c5bf435f281) if you need to reinstall those stand-alone apps.)

   **Notes:**

   - For Microsoft 365 operated by 21 Vianet go to [login.partner.microsoftonline.cn](https://login.partner.microsoftonline.cn/account).

   - For Microsoft 365 Germany go to [portal.office.de](https://portal.office.de/account).

4. This completes the download of Microsoft 365 to your device. To complete the installation, follow the prompts in the "Install Microsoft 365" section below.

   **Tip:**  **Don't see an install option after signing in?** There could be an issue with your account. Select [Need help?](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/download-and-install-or-reinstall-microsoft-365-or-office-2021-on-a-pc-or-mac-4414eaaf-0478-48be-9c42-23adc4716658#installsteps=need_help) from above and review the solutions under **Account questions**.

# Install Office

1. Depending on your browser, select **Run** (in Microsoft Edge or Internet Explorer), **Setup** (in Chrome), or **Save File** (in Firefox).

   If you see the User Account Control prompt that says, **Do you want to allow this app to make changes to your device?** select **Yes**.

   The install begins.

   ![Shows the progress dialog box that appears when Office is installing](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/37afcb50-4ee1-4850-a5ab-5adaac941fdb.png)

2. Your install is finished when you see the phrase, **"You're all set! Office is installed now"** and an animation plays to show you where to find Microsoft 365  applications on your computer. Select **Close**.

   ![Office is installed now. Select Close](https://support.content.office.net/en-us/media/2843cdf3-5877-4ad4-98d5-32fa6e4e8d98.png)

#### Installation or sign in issues?

**Tip:** You can download and install the [Microsoft Support and Recovery Assistant](https://aka.ms/SaRA_OfficeSetup) to help with Microsoft 365 installation issues on a PC. For more information, see [About the Microsoft Support and Recovery Assistant](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/about-the-microsoft-support-and-recovery-assistant-e90bb691-c2a7-4697-a94f-88836856c72f).

If you're having an installation issue such as Microsoft 365 taking long to install, try [Need help?](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/download-and-install-or-reinstall-microsoft-365-or-office-2021-on-a-pc-or-mac-4414eaaf-0478-48be-9c42-23adc4716658#installsteps=need_help) for a list of common issues.

### Activate Microsoft 365 or Office

1. To open an app, select the **Start** button (lower-left corner of your screen) and type the name of an app, like **Word**.

   If you have Windows 8.1 or 8.0, type the name of an Microsoft 365 app on the **Start** screen. [Can't find your Office apps?](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/can-t-find-office-applications-in-windows-10-windows-8-or-windows-7-907ce545-6ae8-459b-8d9d-de6764a635d6)

2. To open the app, select its icon in the search results.

3. When the app opens, accept the license agreement. Microsoft 365 or Office is activated and ready to use.

   **Note:** The Activation Wizard appears if Microsoft 365 or Office has trouble activating. Complete the steps in the wizard to finish activation.

Learn more on what Microsoft 365 can do, [Click here for more information.](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/18169)

body_markdown:
## **Benefits of SAP S/4HANA Migration**

Once you have take the time to invest in this advanced ERP system, you will be amazed to see the benefits you reap sooner or later. The key benefits of SAP HANA migration include:

- It’s a future-proof solution as you can get quarterly updates for your SAP S/4HANA cloud systems.

- The system is easy to use and comes with a simplified user experience, due to which one can make heavy usage of SAP’s new technologies without difficulty.

- The Business Suite data model of SAP has been largely simplified. For instance, SAP has been able to reduce the memory footprint of users’ databases, which makes the system run faster.

- Gain accurate business insights in real-time, thus enhancing your decision-making abilities. This has been made possible by the high-performing analytics engine and a simplified data model, which helps to optimize one’s business processes and work with higher agility.

## **Top 3 Approaches for SAP HANA Migration**

So, we have learned that the SAP HANA migration has great potential for business growth. Now what? To answer that, we will make a proper migration plan based on either of the following approaches.

### **1. The Greenfield Approach**

The Greenfield Approach involves a new implementation of the SAP S/4HANA platform, and it needs a complete transformation on the part of the management. However, this approach can be time-consuming and needs some effort since you need to start the entire process from scratch.

One positive side of this approach is that you can simplify your core business processes and restructure your operations for enhanced output. What’s more, using the Greenfield Approach, you can enjoy the complete benefits of the S/4HANA ERP platform.

If you are willing to take this approach, you need to ensure that you are ready for the entire organization and redefining process. Because for some companies, this can be quite tiresome, especially when they are focusing on short-term goals.

### **2. The Brownfield Approach**

When the Greenfield Approach seems overwhelming or too tiresome, there’s always a second way out – that is the Brownfield Approach. In fact, SAP recommends this method for its existing customers to make the migration easier for them.

In this way, the current customers operating on the SAP ECC system can easily transform while still working on their existing databases without hassle. It makes the migration smoother, easier, and quicker.

The Brownfield process allows you to continue your business operations on your existing systems while slowly adopting the technologies of the new system over time. It helps users to adapt to changes more seamlessly without facing any business discontinuity or disruption.

Although this approach may come with the risks of experiencing more technical issues, the SAP system comes fully equipped with effective solutions to support a seamless flow of your business operations. The best part is, you will get complete guidance and conversion tools to make way for a risk-free migration.

### **3. Landscape Transformation**

The landscape transformation approach doesn’t involve a conversion of the entire system. Instead, it focuses on the transformation of certain portions of the business process only. In other words, you can migrate only the processes you want and continue using the existing systems.

Therefore, the landscape transformation method allows you to make selective migrations or convert the entire system for a more consolidated workflow by integrating SAP and non-SAP systems under one roof. You can first select a particular process that will offer you the highest revenue in short periods. You can always migrate other business processes later as per your needs.

## Key Steps

Migrating to **SAP S/4HANA** is a strategic move for digital transformation. Here's an overview of the key steps:

1. **Assess and Plan**: Evaluate your current ERP landscape, define migration objectives, and create a comprehensive plan.

2. **Landscape Preparation**: Ensure technical prerequisites are met, optimize data, and address custom code adaptations.

3. **Migration Approach**: Choose between system conversion or greenfield implementation based on complexity and desired outcomes.

4. **System Conversion**: Upgrade the existing ERP system, migrate data, transform configurations, and ensure compatibility.

5. **Greenfield Implementation**: Set up a new SAP S/4HANA system, redesigning processes and leveraging the latest functionalities.

6. **Testing and Validation**: Thoroughly test the migrated system, validate data integrity, and address identified issues.

7. **Training and Change Management**: Provide comprehensive user training, educate on new features, and implement change management strategies.

8. **Go-Live and Support**: Execute the final migration, closely monitor system performance, and provide post-migration support.

Engage experienced consultants and follow best practices to ensure a successful migration, unlocking the benefits of **SAP S/4HANA**.

## **Key Takeaway**

Reinvent your business with a transformed working environment and get ready for the future with an optimized ERP solution. Embrace digital innovation through technologies like AI, machine learning, big data, IoT, blockchain, and more.

Accelerate and redefine your organization through three simple steps – a) adopt this new system, b) optimize your business, and c) make the ultimate transformation. So, are you ready to build a future-proof business?

  8. Go-Live and Support: Execute the final migration, closely monitor system performance, and provide post-migration support.

Engage experienced consultants and follow best practices to ensure a successful migration, unlocking the benefits of SAP S/4HANA.

Key Takeaway

Reinvent your business with a transformed working environment and get ready for the future with an optimized ERP solution. Embrace digital innovation through technologies like AI, machine learning, big data, IoT, blockchain, and more.

Accelerate and redefine your organization through three simple steps – a) adopt this new system, b) optimize your business, and c) make the ultimate transformation. So, are you ready to build a future-proof business?

body_markdown:
Integrations allow customers to connect Stack Overflow for Teams with tools they already use. Integrations increase adoption and help SO4T “stick” within an organization.

# Available Integrations:

Our integrations with [Slack](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/slack) and [Microsoft Teams ](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/microsoft-teams)allows team members to ask questions and search for information within the tool that they use the most for synchronous communication.

# Slack

- Post questions and get answers, right from Slack

- Get instant notifications

- Search Stack Overflow for Teams from Slack

- More information can be found on our [website](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/slack/)

- [Using the Slack Integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000245471-using-the-slack-integration)

- [Administrator setup for Slack Integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000260242-administrator-setup-for-slack-integration)

- More in this SO Internal [knowledge article](https://stackoverflow.com/c/stack-overflow/articles/10539)

- [More in this Q&A](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16476)

# Microsoft Teams

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/ee3f97fd-8470-4cec-8e26-46e06904503f.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/ee3f97fd-8470-4cec-8e26-46e06904503f.png)

- Ask questions and get answers, right from Microsoft Teams

- Stop searching past conversations. Capture solutions for future reuse

- Automatic alerts of new and updated knowledge

- More information can be found on our [website](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/microsoft-teams/)

- [Using the Microsoft Teams Integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000251427-using-the-microsoft-teams-integration)

- [Administrator setup for Microsoft Teams integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000251384-administrator-setup-for-microsoft-teams-integration)

- More in this SO Internal [knowledge article](https://stackoverflow.com/c/stack-overflow/articles/13973)

- More in this SO Internal [Q&A](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16920)

Minimize context switching for your technical employees with our [Jira](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/jira) and [GitHub](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/github) integrations. Solve tickets faster and overcome challenges with a direct link to similar questions and answers

# Jira

- for Cloud, not on premise versions

- Surface the right information at the right time without leaving Jira

- Quickly access helpful answers from within Jira

- Embed links to Jira tickets in Stack Overflow

- More information can be found on our [website](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/jira/)

- [Using the Jira Integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000251379-using-the-jira-integration)

- [Administrator setup for Jira Cloud integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000251030-administrator-setup-for-jira-cloud-integration)

- **More in this SO Internal [knowledge article](https://stackoverflow.com/c/stack-overflow/articles/11484)**

- More in this SO Internal [Q&A](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16524)

# Github

- Add context to your code with our GitHub integration

- Find answers to questions on specific PRs, Gists and Commits

- Share key learnings with reference to specific code and projects in GitHub

- More information can be found on our [website](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/github/)

- [Using the GitHub integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000251516-using-the-github-integration)

- [Administrator setup for GitHub integration](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000251514-administrator-setup-for-github-integration)

- **More in this SO Internal [knowledge article](https://stackoverflow.com/c/stack-overflow/articles/11486)**

- More in this SO Internal [Q&A](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16518)

# Okta

- Create an easy and secure login experience, every time.

- Centralized provisioning

- SAML SSO

- Okta Verify OTP

- More information can be found on our [website ](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/okta/)

- [Configuring SAML Authentication with Okta](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000215794-configuring-saml-authentication-with-okta)

Learn more about all our integrations [here](https://stackoverflow.co/teams/integrations/).

body_markdown:
How to manually **configure** a **VPN** on **your iPhone** or iPad

1. Launch **Settings** from **your** Home screen.

2. Tap General. ...

3. Tap **VPN**.

4. Choose Add **VPN** Configuration. ...

5. Tap Type.

6. Select **your VPN** type from IKEv2, IPSec, or L2TP.

7. If you **change your** mind, you can tap on Cancel in the upper left corner to go back.

https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16724
title: Steps on How to Change Your VPN on your iPhone
body:
How to manually configure a VPN on your iPhone or iPad

  1. Launch Settings from your Home screen.

  2. Tap General. ...

  3. Tap VPN.

  4. Choose Add VPN Configuration. ...

  5. Tap Type.

  6. Select your VPN type from IKEv2, IPSec, or L2TP.

  7. If you change your mind, you can tap on Cancel in the upper left corner to go back.

How do I use the Github integration?

body_markdown:
# Create an Azure resource group using Terraform

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| Author | Travis Mahomes |
| Date Added | January 7, 2022 |
| Link to Component | <https://github.com/Azure/terraform/tree/master/quickstart/101-resource-group> |
| FAQ | <https://stackoverflow.com/c/demo/collections/997> |

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| [![](https://stackoverflow.com/c/demo/images/s/39596708-9bc0-4956-9ca3-3caa22aec8a3.png)](https://stackoverflow.com/c/demo/images/s/39596708-9bc0-4956-9ca3-3caa22aec8a3.png) | [![](https://stackoverflow.com/c/demo/images/s/89214676-c2e4-4cb4-9ab7-5f415b39e02d.png)](https://stackoverflow.com/c/demo/images/s/89214676-c2e4-4cb4-9ab7-5f415b39e02d.png) |

# Using the Component

[Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) enables the definition, preview, and deployment of cloud infrastructure. Using Terraform, you create configuration files using [HCL syntax](https://www.terraform.io/docs/configuration/syntax.html). The HCL syntax allows you to specify the cloud provider - such as Azure - and the elements that make up your cloud infrastructure. After you create your configuration files, you create an *execution plan* that allows you to preview your infrastructure changes before they're deployed. Once you verify the changes, you apply the execution plan to deploy the infrastructure.

This article shows how to create an Azure resource group using Terraform.

In this article, you learn how to:

- Create an Azure resource group to hold other Azure resources

- Verify (using Azure CLI and Azure PowerShell) the resource group was created

- Delete the resource group when finished using it

# 1. Configure your environment

- **Azure subscription**: If you don't have an Azure subscription, create a [free account](https://azure.microsoft.com/free/?ref=microsoft.com&utm_source=microsoft.com&utm_medium=docs&utm_campaign=visualstudio) before you begin.

- **Configure Terraform:** If you haven't already done so, configure Terraform using one of the following options:

  - [Configure Terraform in Azure Cloud Shell with Bash](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/developer/terraform/get-started-cloud-shell-bash)

  - [Configure Terraform in Azure Cloud Shell with PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/developer/terraform/get-started-cloud-shell-powershell)

  - [Configure Terraform in Windows with Bash](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/developer/terraform/get-started-windows-bash)

  - [Configure Terraform in Windows with PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/developer/terraform/get-started-windows-powershell)

# 2. Implement the Terraform code

1. Create a directory in which to test the sample Terraform code and make it the current directory.

2. Create a file named `main.tf` and insert the following code:

   terraform {

   required_version = "\>=0.12"

   required_providers {
   azurerm = {
   source = "hashicorp/azurerm"
   version = "\~\>2.0"
   }
   }
   }

   provider "azurerm" {
   features {}
   }

   resource "random_pet" "rg-name" {
   prefix    = var.resource_group_name_prefix
   }

   resource "azurerm_resource_group" "rg" {
   name      = random_pet.rg-name.id
   location  = var.resource_group_location
   }

3\. Create a file named `variables.tf` to contain the project variables and insert the following code:

    variable "resource_group_name_prefix" {
      default       = "rg"
      description   = "Prefix of the resource group name that's combined with a random ID so name is unique in your Azure subscription."
    }
    
    variable "resource_group_location" {
      default = "eastus"
      description   = "Location of the resource group."
    }

4\. Create a file named `output.tf` to display the randomly generated resource group name and insert the following code:

    output "resource_group_name" {
        value = azurerm_resource_group.rg.name
    }

# 3. Initialize Terraform

Run [terraform init](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/init.html) to initialize the Terraform deployment. This command downloads the Azure modules required to manage your Azure resources.

    terraform init

# 4. Create a Terraform execution plan

Run [terraform plan](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/plan.html) to create an execution plan.

    terraform plan -out main.tfplan

**Key points:**

- The `terraform plan` command creates an execution plan, but doesn't execute it. Instead, it determines what actions are necessary to create the configuration specified in your configuration files. This pattern allows you to verify whether the execution plan matches your expectations before making any changes to actual resources.

- The optional `-out` parameter allows you to specify an output file for the plan. Using the `-out` parameter ensures that the plan you reviewed is exactly what is applied.

- To read more about persisting execution plans and security, see the [security warning section](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/plan.html#security-warning).

# 5. Apply a Terraform execution plan

Run [terraform apply](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/apply.html) to apply the execution plan to your cloud infrastructure.

    terraform apply main.tfplan

**Key points:**

- The `terraform apply` command above assumes you previously ran `terraform plan -out main.tfplan`.

- If you specified a different filename for the `-out` parameter, use that same filename in the call to `terraform apply`.

- If you didn't use the `-out` parameter, simply call `terraform apply` without any parameters.

# 6. Verify the results

Run [az group show](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/group#az_group_show) to display the resource group.

    az group show --name <resource_group_name>

**Key points:**

- The resource group name is displayed in the `terraform apply` output.

# 7. Clean up resources

When you no longer need the resources created via Terraform, do the following steps:

1. Run [terraform plan](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/plan.html) and specify the `destroy` flag.

   terraform plan -destroy -out main.destroy.tfplan

**Key points:**

- The `terraform plan` command creates an execution plan, but doesn't execute it. Instead, it determines what actions are necessary to create the configuration specified in your configuration files. This pattern allows you to verify whether the execution plan matches your expectations before making any changes to actual resources.

- The optional `-out` parameter allows you to specify an output file for the plan. Using the `-out` parameter ensures that the plan you reviewed is exactly what is applied.

- To read more about persisting execution plans and security, see the [security warning section](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/plan.html#security-warning).

2\. Run [terraform apply](https://www.terraform.io/docs/commands/apply.html) to apply the execution plan.

    terraform apply main.destroy.tfplan

# Troubleshoot Terraform on Azure

[Troubleshoot common problems when using Terraform on Azure](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/developer/terraform/troubleshoot)

# Next steps

**[Learn more about using Terraform in Azure](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/terraform)**
title: Create an Azure resource group using Terraform

Create an Azure resource group using Terraform
Author Travis Mahomes
Date Added January 7, 2022
Link to Component https://github.com/Azure/terraform/tree/master/quickstart/101-resource-group
FAQ https://stackoverflow.com/c/demo/collections/997

Using the Component

Terraform enables the definition, preview, and deployment of cloud infrastructure. Using Terraform, you create configuration files using HCL syntax. The HCL syntax allows you to specify the cloud provider - such as Azure - and the elements that make up your cloud infrastructure. After you create your configuration files, you create an execution plan that allows you to preview your infrastructure changes before they're deployed. Once you verify the changes, you apply the execution plan to deploy the infrastructure.

This article shows how to create an Azure resource group using Terraform.

In this article, you learn how to:

  • Create an Azure resource group to hold other Azure resources

  • Verify (using Azure CLI and Azure PowerShell) the resource group was created

  • Delete the resource group when finished using it

1. Configure your environment

  • Azure subscription: If you don't have an Azure subscription, create a free account before you begin.

  • Configure Terraform: If you haven't already done so, configure Terraform using one of the following options:

    • Configure Terraform in Azure Cloud Shell with Bash

    • Configure Terraform in Azure Cloud Shell with PowerShell

    • Configure Terraform in Windows with Bash

    • Configure Terraform in Windows with PowerShell

2. Implement the Terraform code

  1. Create a directory in which to test the sample Terraform code and make it the current directory.

  2. Create a file named main.tf and insert the following code:

    terraform {

    required_version = ">=0.12"

    required_providers { azurerm = { source = "hashicorp/azurerm" version = "~>2.0" } } }

    provider "azurerm" { features {} }

    resource "random_pet" "rg-name" { prefix = var.resource_group_name_prefix }

    resource "azurerm_resource_group" "rg" { name = random_pet.rg-name.id location = var.resource_group_location }

3. Create a file named variables.tf to contain the project variables and insert the following code:

variable "resource_group_name_prefix" {
  default       = "rg"
  description   = "Prefix of the resource group name that's combined with a random ID so name is unique in your Azure subscription."
}

variable "resource_group_location" {
  default = "eastus"
  description   = "Location of the resource group."
}

4. Create a file named output.tf to display the randomly generated resource group name and insert the following code:

output "resource_group_name" {
    value = azurerm_resource_group.rg.name
}

3. Initialize Terraform

Run terraform init to initialize the Terraform deployment. This command downloads the Azure modules required to manage your Azure resources.

terraform init

4. Create a Terraform execution plan

Run terraform plan to create an execution plan.

Key points:

  • The terraform plan command creates an execution plan, but doesn't execute it. Instead, it determines what actions are necessary to create the configuration specified in your configuration files. This pattern allows you to verify whether the execution plan matches your expectations before making any changes to actual resources.

  • The optional -out parameter allows you to specify an output file for the plan. Using the -out parameter ensures that the plan you reviewed is exactly what is applied.

  • To read more about persisting execution plans and security, see the security warning section.

5. Apply a Terraform execution plan

Run terraform apply to apply the execution plan to your cloud infrastructure.

Key points:

  • The terraform apply command above assumes you previously ran terraform plan -out main.tfplan.

  • If you specified a different filename for the -out parameter, use that same filename in the call to terraform apply.

  • If you didn't use the -out parameter, simply call terraform apply without any parameters.

6. Verify the results

Run az group show to display the resource group.

az group show --name <resource_group_name>

Key points:

  • The resource group name is displayed in the terraform apply output.

7. Clean up resources

When you no longer need the resources created via Terraform, do the following steps:

  1. Run terraform plan and specify the destroy flag.

    terraform plan -destroy -out main.destroy.tfplan

Key points:

  • The terraform plan command creates an execution plan, but doesn't execute it. Instead, it determines what actions are necessary to create the configuration specified in your configuration files. This pattern allows you to verify whether the execution plan matches your expectations before making any changes to actual resources.

  • The optional -out parameter allows you to specify an output file for the plan. Using the -out parameter ensures that the plan you reviewed is exactly what is applied.

  • To read more about persisting execution plans and security, see the security warning section.

2. Run terraform apply to apply the execution plan.

terraform apply main.destroy.tfplan

Troubleshoot Terraform on Azure

body_markdown:
Every employee's journey through your organization begins at onboarding. Does your onboarding welcome new employees into the fold, and set them up for longevity?

# **Components of good onboarding**

----------

At Stack Overflow, we use our own knowledge sharing and collaboration platform, Stack Overflow for Teams, as an integral part of the onboarding process. Our onboarding process comprises four components:The components of good onboarding

- Content

- Culture

- Inter-departmental transparency

- Future planning

----------

# **Content**

Creating and managing content is how you ensure all of those policies are communicated during onboarding. From password processes and initial security measures to the company mission and the review cycle structure, you’ll be documenting everything.

At Stack Overflow, all of our internal knowledge lives on Stack Overflow for Teams. New hires (and not-so-new hires!) are free to revisit it at any time. The information stays current, because people are updating it all the time with the latest knowledge. Whatever you use, you should make sure that your new hires have continuous access to onboarding information. Write articles, how-to guides, checklists, or company hierarchies and contact information. Then make sure that information is visible to all.

What type of content should you develop? Here are some ideas taken directly from our onboarding:

- Employee handbooks

- Processes and procedures

- History of the product(s)

- History of the organization

- Tests and results

- Company updates

- “First 12 weeks at \[Company\]” checklist

**Question - [Virtual Desktop Setup](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/17889)**

----------

# **Culture**

There’s a direct relationship between how much an employee understands the corporate culture and how quickly they can integrate into their team. You will need to explain the components of the culture and give pointers right away.

While “culture” can have several definitions, think about the specifics of your organizational culture handles situations like the following:

- How do people work together - is it mostly autonomous, or heavy on the teamwork and communication?

- Do you frequently use meetings to hash things out, or do people try to limit meetings to strictly when necessary?

- How do people in your organization socialize? When and where do people have fun and bond?

- What extracurricular activities are available?

- Where should a new hire look for mentorship?

- How do your company’s mission and values filter down into the day-to-day?

----------

# Inter-departmental transparency

The best answers to questions can come from anywhere. But the first step, for new hires, is knowing exactly where “anywhere” is. Does your organization have one Design department, or are specific product-focused designers placed on different teams? How does content and marketing work? Who is involved in the software engineering lifecycle?

Org charts and subject matter experts’ contact information should be widely accessible. As you create your onboarding framework, think about how to surface contacts and useful information from every department, and make it accessible beyond the confines of that specific team.

----------

# Future planning

One of your major goals with onboarding is to show new hires that they can have a long and fulfilling career within your organization. With Stack Overflow for Teams, you can apply the practices of onboarding across all seniority levels and tenures.

For example, after someone receives a promotion, or transfers to a new team, or comes back from a sabbatical.

Onboarding is about personal progression. A new hire’s progression doesn’t need to stop, just because they “age out” of being a new hire. So try to extend your onboarding best practices to all employees in all situations. What does that look like?

- Mapping key goals and milestone

- Laying out the best practices for moving from an individual contributor to a manager with direct reports

- Creating spaces for an employee to develop something new (like Google’s famous 20% projects)

- Laying out expectations at each rung of the corporate ladder

- Use cases and success stories around experiments, a new practice, an insight uncovered, or cross-team collaboration

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/0b3e2dfe-82e6-45c1-93fc-00c8ee508062.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/0b3e2dfe-82e6-45c1-93fc-00c8ee508062.png)

We put this “continuous onboarding” philosophy to work through Stack Overflow for Teams. We’ve created “[Collections](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/16555)” for many of our internal teams. Collections are groups of articles, Q&As, how-to guides, and other useful information about a certain topic. These collections are easily searchable and anyone can contribute to them.

That way, employees at all stages of their careers feel empowered to harness the collected wisdom of their peers. We have collections around topics like “How to talk about Stack Overflow”, “Customer success collateral”, “Enterprise architecture”, “Managing people,” and more.
title: Onboarding as Engineer

body_markdown:
We use our billing system to ensure that we receive timely and accurate payment from our customers. If  you are in a role that requires access to this system, please use the following setup instructions. 

Billing System Setup Instructions 

Submit a ticket to the IT helpdesk to request an account with the proper permissions
Confirm email address and set up account with multi-factor authentication 
Log in and confirm that the list of assigned accounts is correct

Initiate a Bill 

Navigate to the homepage and select the appropriate account 
Select “Create New Invoice” 
Ensure that the line items are correct 
Once ready - select “Go Live” - The bill will follow our approval process before being sent to the client. 

To view more training and documentation - view these resources
title: Billing Setup
body:
We use our billing system to ensure that we receive timely and accurate payment from our customers. If you are in a role that requires access to this system, please use the following setup instructions.

Billing System Setup Instructions

Submit a ticket to the IT helpdesk to request an account with the proper permissions Confirm email address and set up account with multi-factor authentication Log in and confirm that the list of assigned accounts is correct

Initiate a Bill

Navigate to the homepage and select the appropriate account Select “Create New Invoice” Ensure that the line items are correct Once ready - select “Go Live” - The bill will follow our approval process before being sent to the client.

To view more training and documentation - view these resources

**![](https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/qDgW_-7cSCxsLSFyZ0HvFJEvlZYPpf0JM6YBVewTUQqyYD9zduvE_LFV4IxyGQlz544Bi1bbWW4awhLzBclTR0cxt-Y_1CM-k50Vu8fT9Ohx86NsszMIViSXDtJGL_NNlnBnV4RH)**

**Title:** Fairly self explanatory. The Headline of your question![](https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/siEatHWmPGJFca1u48-qG2ajori0UilHclp8tivoSDbkOgN0fnjoR2UggpuD4ThGy-uU9K6fd4PfLiE8MweAeHYWhtkt860cnDxZJJaTPjIYL7FUFRF_jfUozEtc4Hg8G-U9t_UI)

- **Similar questions search**. As you type in your question title, we search for existing questions that have already been asked.

**Why are we talking about this?** Helps prevent duplicate questions being asked.

- 2 or 3 of the same question, with different answers leaves users with no confidence in the content

- What usecase/s does this address?

****

**How to boxes:** Here we’ve more customisation, you’re able to edit the text on the below: ![](https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/s1ELNvHRNXu68q6qcaZrpBW5rBqyR0tIJblVtXYtC8nlyQe8fdiTRwEeVSMs6HvXw76l6PhWUxSq8nQYA_050vgrzvjrK503Ey0kHe3QX0VgsaKo9zXPyma0xmsIX2vGMMV6V6XB)

- How to ask box

- How to Tag box

- How to Format box

**Why are we talking about this?** Helps guide users on the type of content they should be entering, as well as how they should be entering it

- Can add links to external docs

- What usecase/s does this address?

****

**Body:** This is where we enter the question detail. The below options help us with rich formatting:

- Images (Max 2mb)

- Codeblocks

- Supports Markdown

- Hyperlinks

- If you’re using our GitHib or Jira (Cloud) integrations you can paste links here, to unfurl within the question

  - Also available on Answers

- Languages supported:

  - **Confirm**

**Why are we talking about this?**

- Gives context

- **Add more**

**Tags:** We structure our content via tags. If you look at our public sites, the tags all revolve around the specific topic of the site.

**Why are we talking about this?**

- *We’ll be covering tags in more detail later on!*

- One of the major benefits of enterprise is that you create and control your own tags.

  - It's helpful to mention the Customer Success team at this point. Tagging systems often have the perception of being difficult to manage. The CS team will help the prospect create a tagging strategy

  - The moderation team can also help with tag management

**Ask a team member:** This is our first feature that isn’t available on the public site (Beyond customisation and content) we can use this to ping an individual, or a predefined group of people *(Set up via Groups - Covered later)*.

- Notified via: Email, a platform message, message on Slack or Microsoft Teams, if using those integrations.

**Answer your own question:** This is a nice little short cut, so a user can quickly ask and answer a question that they’re frequently being asked.
title: How do i ask a Question?
body:
Title: Fairly self explanatory. The Headline of your question

  • Similar questions search. As you type in your question title, we search for existing questions that have already been asked.

Why are we talking about this? Helps prevent duplicate questions being asked.

  • 2 or 3 of the same question, with different answers leaves users with no confidence in the content

  • What usecase/s does this address?

How to boxes: Here we’ve more customisation, you’re able to edit the text on the below: 

  • How to ask box

  • How to Tag box

  • How to Format box

Why are we talking about this? Helps guide users on the type of content they should be entering, as well as how they should be entering it

  • Can add links to external docs

  • What usecase/s does this address?

  • Images (Max 2mb)

  • Supports Markdown

  • If you’re using our GitHib or Jira (Cloud) integrations you can paste links here, to unfurl within the question

    • Also available on Answers

  • Languages supported:

    • Confirm

Why are we talking about this?

  • Gives context

  • Add more

Tags: We structure our content via tags. If you look at our public sites, the tags all revolve around the specific topic of the site.

Why are we talking about this?

  • We’ll be covering tags in more detail later on!

  • One of the major benefits of enterprise is that you create and control your own tags.

    • It's helpful to mention the Customer Success team at this point. Tagging systems often have the perception of being difficult to manage. The CS team will help the prospect create a tagging strategy

    • The moderation team can also help with tag management

Ask a team member: This is our first feature that isn’t available on the public site (Beyond customisation and content) we can use this to ping an individual, or a predefined group of people (Set up via Groups - Covered later).

Answer your own question: This is a nice little short cut, so a user can quickly ask and answer a question that they’re frequently being asked.

body_markdown:
**Short description of our Microsoft Teams integration**

Our out-of-the-box Microsoft Teams integration empowers users to discover knowledge, solve challenges, and capture solutions for future use without leaving their current workstreams.

**Long description of the integration**

Stack Overflow for Team’s out-of-the-box Microsoft Teams integration empowers users to access the organization’s collective knowledge to solve blockages without switching between applications or disrupting team members. The native Stack Overflow for Teams experience within Microsoft Teams empowers users to search for answers, ask questions, proactively review new knowledge, and capture solutions for future reuse all without leaving their preferred workflow.

**What are the features and the associated benefits?**

1\. Minimize context switching by searching for critical knowledge without leaving Microsoft Teams.

- If a teammate asks a question within Microsoft Teams, search and share verified knowledge from Stack Overflow for Teams using the messaging extension within the channel. \[NEW\]

  - Searching via the messaging extension will show results to the user, but sharing via the “post” button on the results, everyone in the channel can benefit from the knowledge. \[NEW\]

  - View, follow or bookmark the search results for more context and to keep up as knowledge evolves. \[NEW\]

- Search organizational knowledge within Stack Overflow for Teams using the channel bot action. Search results will display within the channel for quick access, and the search results will display to everyone within the channel.

2\. Capture knowledge and solutions for reuse from within Microsoft Teams.

- Convert a post within Microsoft Teams to a question within Stack Overflow for Teams using the messaging extension. An ask modal will display within Microsoft Teams, helping to minimize the need to switch between applications. \[NEW\]

  - If a user needs help filling out all of the details within the question, teammates can chime in and finish asking the question.\[NEW\]

- Ask a question using the channel bot and receive the best matching result directly in the chat. Minimize team distractions by accessing existing knowledge, and if there are no answers to your question, receive a prompt to ask on Stack Overflow for Teams.

3\. Enable employees to be more efficient by accessing pertinent knowledge from Stack Overflow for Teams within the new tab. \[NEW\]

- Reuse knowledge before tapping into teammates. View a list of Questions or Articles (Business and Enterprise only) that can be filtered by tags that are applicable to the channel.

4\. Create an oasis of knowledge tailored to a user within a personal app. Quickly access solutions to resolve issues or stay up-to-date with the latest knowledge that may be needed in the future. \[NEW\]

- Access important knowledge including your bookmarks, Questions and Articles using the personal app.

5\. Stay up-to-date through automated notifications of new or updated knowledge.

- Set up tag-based push notification to share new questions, answers, comments, and Articles directly a channel within Microsoft Teams

- Get a preview of new knowledge related to a tag without leaving Microsoft Teams.

- Create new notifications or edit existing notifications quickly by interacting with the channel bot within Microsoft Teams.

body_markdown:
Decision tree elements\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Decision_tree&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Decision tree elements")\]

![Decision-Tree-Elements.png](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Decision-Tree-Elements.png)

Drawn from left to right, a decision tree has only burst nodes (splitting paths) but no sink nodes (converging paths). Therefore, used manually, they can grow very big and are then often hard to draw fully by hand. Traditionally, decision trees have been created manually – as the aside example shows – although increasingly, specialized software is employed.

### Decision rules\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Decision_tree&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Decision rules")\]

The decision tree can be [linearized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linearization "Linearization") into **decision rules**,\<sup\>[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree#cite_note-2)\</sup\> where the outcome is the contents of the leaf node, and the conditions along the path form a conjunction in the if clause. In general, the rules have the form:

if condition1 *and* condition2 *and* condition3 *then* outcome.

Decision rules can be generated by constructing [association rules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_rule_learning "Association rule learning") with the target variable on the right. They can also denote [temporal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time "Time") or [causal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal "Causal") relations.\<sup\>[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_tree#cite_note-3)\</sup\>

### Decision tree using flowchart symbols\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Decision_tree&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Decision tree using flowchart symbols")\]

Commonly a decision tree is drawn using [flowchart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flowchart "Flowchart") symbols as it is easier for many to read and understand. Note there is a conceptual error in the "Proceed" calculation of the tree shown below; the error relates to the calculation of "costs" awarded in a legal action.

More information [here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/9735)
title: Decision Trees
body:
Decision tree elements[edit]

Drawn from left to right, a decision tree has only burst nodes (splitting paths) but no sink nodes (converging paths). Therefore, used manually, they can grow very big and are then often hard to draw fully by hand. Traditionally, decision trees have been created manually – as the aside example shows – although increasingly, specialized software is employed.

Decision rules[edit]

The decision tree can be linearized into decision rules,<sup>[2]</sup> where the outcome is the contents of the leaf node, and the conditions along the path form a conjunction in the if clause. In general, the rules have the form:

if condition1 and condition2 and condition3 then outcome.

Decision rules can be generated by constructing association rules with the target variable on the right. They can also denote temporal or causal relations.<sup>[3]</sup>

Decision tree using flowchart symbols[edit]

Commonly a decision tree is drawn using flowchart symbols as it is easier for many to read and understand. Note there is a conceptual error in the "Proceed" calculation of the tree shown below; the error relates to the calculation of "costs" awarded in a legal action.

More information here

body_markdown:
**\*\*Test for Customer Training\*\***

Every employee's journey through your organization begins at onboarding. Does your onboarding welcome new employees into the fold, and set them up for longevity?

# **Components of good onboarding**

----------

At Stack Overflow, we use our own knowledge sharing and collaboration platform, Stack Overflow for Teams, as an integral part of the onboarding process. Our onboarding process comprises four components:The components of good onboarding

- Content

- Culture

- Inter-departmental transparency

- Future planning

----------

# **Content**

Creating and managing content is how you ensure all of those policies are communicated during onboarding. From password processes and initial security measures to the company mission and the review cycle structure, you’ll be documenting everything.

At Stack Overflow, all of our internal knowledge lives on Stack Overflow for Teams. New hires (and not-so-new hires!) are free to revisit it at any time. The information stays current, because people are updating it all the time with the latest knowledge. Whatever you use, you should make sure that your new hires have continuous access to onboarding information. Write articles, how-to guides, checklists, or company hierarchies and contact information. Then make sure that information is visible to all.

What type of content should you develop? Here are some ideas taken directly from our onboarding:

- Employee handbooks

- Processes and procedures

- History of the product(s)

- History of the organization

- Tests and results

- Company updates

- “First 12 weeks at \[Company\]” checklist

**Question - [Virtual Desktop Setup](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/17889)**

----------

# **Culture**

There’s a direct relationship between how much an employee understands the corporate culture and how quickly they can integrate into their team. You will need to explain the components of the culture and give pointers right away.

While “culture” can have several definitions, think about the specifics of your organizational culture handles situations like the following:

- How do people work together - is it mostly autonomous, or heavy on the teamwork and communication?

- Do you frequently use meetings to hash things out, or do people try to limit meetings to strictly when necessary?

- How do people in your organization socialize? When and where do people have fun and bond?

- What extracurricular activities are available?

- Where should a new hire look for mentorship?

- How do your company’s mission and values filter down into the day-to-day?

----------

# Inter-departmental transparency

The best answers to questions can come from anywhere. But the first step, for new hires, is knowing exactly where “anywhere” is. Does your organization have one Design department, or are specific product-focused designers placed on different teams? How does content and marketing work? Who is involved in the software engineering lifecycle?

Org charts and subject matter experts’ contact information should be widely accessible. As you create your onboarding framework, think about how to surface contacts and useful information from every department, and make it accessible beyond the confines of that specific team.

----------

# Future planning

One of your major goals with onboarding is to show new hires that they can have a long and fulfilling career within your organization. With Stack Overflow for Teams, you can apply the practices of onboarding across all seniority levels and tenures.

For example, after someone receives a promotion, or transfers to a new team, or comes back from a sabbatical.

Onboarding is about personal progression. A new hire’s progression doesn’t need to stop, just because they “age out” of being a new hire. So try to extend your onboarding best practices to all employees in all situations. What does that look like?

- Mapping key goals and milestone

- Laying out the best practices for moving from an individual contributor to a manager with direct reports

- Creating spaces for an employee to develop something new (like Google’s famous 20% projects)

- Laying out expectations at each rung of the corporate ladder

- Use cases and success stories around experiments, a new practice, an insight uncovered, or cross-team collaboration

[![enter image description here](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/0b3e2dfe-82e6-45c1-93fc-00c8ee508062.png)](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/images/a/0b3e2dfe-82e6-45c1-93fc-00c8ee508062.png)

We put this “continuous onboarding” philosophy to work through Stack Overflow for Teams. We’ve created “[Collections](https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/articles/16555)” for many of our internal teams. Collections are groups of articles, Q&As, how-to guides, and other useful information about a certain topic. These collections are easily searchable and anyone can contribute to them.

That way, employees at all stages of their careers feel empowered to harness the collected wisdom of their peers. We have collections around topics like “How to talk about Stack Overflow”, “Customer success collateral”, “Enterprise architecture”, “Managing people,” and more.
title: Test - Onboarding New Hires with Stack Overflow for Teams

There’s a direct relationship between how much an employee understands the corporate culture and how quickly they can integrate into their team. You will need to explain the components of the culture and give pointers right away.

While “culture” can have several definitions, think about the specifics of your organizational culture handles situations like the following:

  • How do people work together - is it mostly autonomous, or heavy on the teamwork and communication?

  • Do you frequently use meetings to hash things out, or do people try to limit meetings to strictly when necessary?

  • How do people in your organization socialize? When and where do people have fun and bond?

  • What extracurricular activities are available?

  • Where should a new hire look for mentorship?

  • How do your company’s mission and values filter down into the day-to-day?

Inter-departmental transparency

The best answers to questions can come from anywhere. But the first step, for new hires, is knowing exactly where “anywhere” is. Does your organization have one Design department, or are specific product-focused designers placed on different teams? How does content and marketing work? Who is involved in the software engineering lifecycle?

Org charts and subject matter experts’ contact information should be widely accessible. As you create your onboarding framework, think about how to surface contacts and useful information from every department, and make it accessible beyond the confines of that specific team.

Future planning

One of your major goals with onboarding is to show new hires that they can have a long and fulfilling career within your organization. With Stack Overflow for Teams, you can apply the practices of onboarding across all seniority levels and tenures.

For example, after someone receives a promotion, or transfers to a new team, or comes back from a sabbatical.

Onboarding is about personal progression. A new hire’s progression doesn’t need to stop, just because they “age out” of being a new hire. So try to extend your onboarding best practices to all employees in all situations. What does that look like?

  • Mapping key goals and milestone

  • Laying out the best practices for moving from an individual contributor to a manager with direct reports

  • Creating spaces for an employee to develop something new (like Google’s famous 20% projects)

  • Laying out expectations at each rung of the corporate ladder

  • Use cases and success stories around experiments, a new practice, an insight uncovered, or cross-team collaboration

We put this “continuous onboarding” philosophy to work through Stack Overflow for Teams. We’ve created “Collections” for many of our internal teams. Collections are groups of articles, Q&As, how-to guides, and other useful information about a certain topic. These collections are easily searchable and anyone can contribute to them.

That way, employees at all stages of their careers feel empowered to harness the collected wisdom of their peers. We have collections around topics like “How to talk about Stack Overflow”, “Customer success collateral”, “Enterprise architecture”, “Managing people,” and more.

body_markdown:
# Using the Component

[Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) enables the definition, preview, and deployment of cloud infrastructure. Using Terraform, you create configuration files using [HCL syntax](https://www.terraform.io/docs/configuration/syntax.html). The HCL syntax allows you to specify the cloud provider - such as Azure - and the elements that make up your cloud infrastructure. After you create your configuration files, you can create an *execution plan* that allows you to preview your infrastructure changes before they're deployed. Once you verify the changes, you apply the execution plan to deploy the infrastructure.

This article shows how to create an Azure resource group using Terraform.

In this article, you learn how to:

- Create an Azure resource group to hold other Azure resources

- Verify (using Azure CLI and Azure PowerShell) the resource group was created

- Delete the resource group when finished using it
title: Using the Azure Component

Using the Component

The HCL syntax allows you to specify the cloud provider - such as Azure - and the elements that make up your cloud infrastructure. After you create your configuration files, you can create an execution plan that allows you to preview your infrastructure changes before they're deployed. Once you verify the changes, you apply the execution plan to deploy the infrastructure.

This article shows how to create an Azure resource group using Terraform.

In this article, you learn how to:

  • Create an Azure resource group to hold other Azure resources

  • Verify (using Azure CLI and Azure PowerShell) the resource group was created

  • Delete the resource group when finished using it

body_markdown:
# What It Does

Create, track, and manage orders in your web and mobile applications.

## On this page

- [Overview](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#overview)

- [Orders components](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#orders-components)

- [Integrating with the Orders API](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#integrating-with-the-orders-api)

  - [Square Point of Sale](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#square-point-of-sale)

  - [Payments](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#payments)

  - [Catalog](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#catalog)

  - [Customers](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#customers)

- [Related topics](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/what-it-does#related-topics)

## 

## Overview

The Orders API integrate parts of the Square ecosystem to track and manage the lifecycle of a purchase. The API can record purchase items, calculate totals, confirm payment, track an order's progress through fulfillment, and update a catalog inventory.

With the Orders API, you can build web and mobile applications that use orders to manage purchase item information, track order fulfillment, integrate customer data, and link payments. You can also create fulfillment orders and send them to the Square Point of Sale application for fulfillment.

### Important

If you use the Square Orders API with a non-Square payments provider, Square charges a transaction fee. For more information, see [Orders API fee structure.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/payments-pricing#orders-api-fee-structure)

## 

## Orders components

The Orders API works with the following key data types:

- `Order`. The top-level container for order information. Order objects include fields for line item details, fulfillment details, and order summary data, including the location ID credited with the order and the total amount of taxes collected.

- `OrderLineItem`. Represents a purchase item (for example, a coffee or T-shirt). Each line item has a `OrderLineItemModifier` that represents an available size or color. Items and modifiers can be built from Catalog objects or they can be defined ad hoc (at the time of creation).

- `OrderLineItemDiscount` and `OrderLineItemTax`. A price modifier that can be applied at the order or line item level. Taxes and discounts can be configured as Catalog objects and referenced in the order or they can be created ad hoc.

- `OrderFulfillment`. Contains details about how to fulfill this order, such as the customer name or the time at which the customer should pick up the order. Order objects made with fulfillments are pushed to the Square Seller Dashboard when charged, so sellers can manage order fulfillment in the Square Point of Sale application.

- `OrderSource`. Tracks the digital or physical source of the order. Orders can be searched or retrieved by the source.

For more information, see [Orders objects and data types.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/how-it-works#orders-objects-and-datatypes)

## 

## Integrating with the Orders API

The Orders API integrates seamlessly with other Square APIs and resources to expand the functionality of your application.

### 

### Square Point of Sale

Orders with fulfillment that have been fully paid are pushed to the Square Point of Sale application, so that sellers can manage fulfillment with the Square Point of Sale application. The Orders API currently supports two types of fulfillment orders: Pickup and Shipment. For more information, see [Add fulfillment details.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/create-orders#add-fulfillment-details)

### 

### Payments

Link your payments to Order objects to itemize sales and apply price modifiers such as taxes, discounts, and service charges. You can also use the Orders API to retrieve any payment activity associated with a sale, whether from the Square Point of Sale application, invoices, or an integration build with the Payments API and Orders API. For more information, see [Pay for Orders.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/pay-for-orders)

### 

### Catalog

Line items, line item modifiers, taxes, and discounts can all be defined as catalog objects. The Orders API reaches its full range of capabilities when orders are built using Square [catalog objects.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/catalog-api/what-it-does)

Key advantages to using catalog items include:

- Orders that reference catalog IDs for taxes and discounts are automatically calculated and applied these price modifiers.

- Orders that reference catalog line items use details defined in the catalog, such as the item name and price.

- When these orders are closed, Square updates the inventory for those items.

Take some time to [set up your catalog with the Catalog API](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/catalog-api/build-with-catalog) to unlock the full range of capabilities from the Orders API. For more information, see [Create Orders.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/create-orders)

### Did you know?

Orders can also be built from ad hoc line items defined at the time of Order object creation. You need to supply an item name and price.

### 

### Customers

Order objects can reference a customer profile. You can later use `SearchOrders` to search orders by customer. For more information about making customer profiles, see [Keep Records of Customer Profiles.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/customers-api/use-the-api/keep-records)

### Important

The Orders API integration with the Customers API is in beta. For more information about known beta issues, see [the changelog.](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/changelog/connect-logs/2019-08-15)

### 

### Customer assignments for orders and payments

In the Seller Dashboard, transaction activity is based on the `customer_id` of the order and other related settings, but the `customer_id` of the payment is ignored. For example, if the order does not have a customer assignment, the transaction's **Paid by** field might not display the customer who is assigned to the payment. To reliably link transactions to customers in the Seller Dashboard, make sure to specify the `customer_id` field in your `CreateOrder` request.

In addition, omitting this field on the `Order` object might result in the creation of new [instant profiles](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/customers-api/what-it-does?preview=true#instant-profiles) that are linked to the payment.

## Related topics

- [Create Orders](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/create-orders)

- [Pay for Orders](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/pay-for-orders)

- [Manage Orders](https://developer.squareup.com/docs/orders-api/manage-orders)

- [Video: Manage orders with the Orders API](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sldn3byppJU&t=5s)
title: New API release
