25 Earth Day Facts—Plus, How to Help the Planet Even While 'Social Distancing'

To learn about how to celebrate, click here.

25 facts about Earth Day

1. Gaylord Nelson, a senator from Wisconsin, founded Earth Day in 1970 to raise public consciousness about environmental concerns such as pollution, oil spills and vanishing wildlife. He tapped into the energy of the anti-war movement, framing Earth Day as a “national teach-in on the environment.”

2. April 22 was chosen as the date for Earth Day because it fell between Spring Break and final exams, and organizers wanted to maximize student involvement.

3. Twenty million Americans, or about 10 percent of the country’s population at the time, took part in events and demonstrations on the first Earth Day.

Related: Things to Do With Kids

4. The first Earth Day pushed environmental concerns onto the national agenda. That same year, Congress authorized the creation of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

5. The first Earth Day in 1970 inspired the passage of the Clean Air, Clean Water and Endangered Species Acts, according to the EPA.

6. The theme for Earth Day 2020 is Climate Action.

7. Around 1 billion people take part in Earth Day activities around the world every year.

8. In the lead-up to Earth Day this year, millions of people worldwide will participate in Earth Hour on March 28. At 8:30 p.m. local time, people will participate in events and demonstrate their commitment to the planet. In past years, Earth Hour gatherings have contributed to real policy changes, including the creation of a marine-protected area in Argentina and environmental protection legislation in Russia.

WWF’s Earth Hour is the world’s largest grassroots movement for the planet that gives us an opportunity to demonstrate our commitment to the planet. In light of the coronavirus crisis, Earth Hour will be celebrated digitally this year.

9. On Earth Day in 2011, people planted 28 million trees in Afghanistan as part of a “Plant Trees Not Bombs” campaign.

10. Since the first Earth Day, average annual temperatures in the contiguous United States have been warming at a rate of 0.45°F per decade.

11. Humans today use about 50 percent more natural resources than we did 30 years ago, according to a report from Friends of the Earth.

12. Animal species populations saw an overall decline of 60 percent worldwide between 1970 and 2014, due to habitat loss, pollution, climate change and other factors, according to the WWF.

13. 2019 was the second-hottest year on record worldwide, just behind 2016, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

14. Twenty of the warmest years on record worldwide have occurred in the past 22 years, according to Climate Central.

15. Scientists estimate that dozens of plants and animal species go extinct each day due to human activity.

16. Rising global temperatures are leading to more extreme weather events, including more intense wildfires and more frequent, high-intensity hurricanes, according to the Earth Day Network.

17. The world’s population is expected to increase from 7 billion today to 9 billion in 2020, which will only increase the impact of human activity on the environment, according to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

18. Today’s average American generates about 4.5 pounds of trash per day, compared to 2.68 pounds in 1960, according to the EPA.

19. Food accounts for 10 to 30 percent of a household’s carbon footprint, due to the emissions involved in food production and transportation, according to the Center for Sustainable Systems.

20. U.S. automobile fuel economy increased 24 percent between 2004 and 2017.

21. You can improve your car’s fuel economy by 7 to 14 percent simply by obeying the speed limit.

22. Electronic devices plugged in on “standby” mode can account for 5 to 10 percent of a household’s energy use.

23. Using a dishwasher is more eco-friendly than hand-washing dishes, according to a recent study from the University of Michigan.

24. Nearly 80 percent of all plastic waste ever created by humans is still in the environment, according to Recycle Now.

25. More than 30 countries and regions have introduced bans on disposable plastic bags to fight plastic waste, according to Greenpeace.

<https://innersourcecommons.org/>

[The Innersource Commons ](https://docs.google.com/document/d/166TzLVQ4C1rUc-rCIuc2RVWWesFLJbe7FhUpDzFEalY/edit#heading=h.u2u051mqrqaz)

### What is InnerSource?

InnerSource takes the lessons learned from developing open source software and applies them to the way companies develop software internally. As developers have become accustomed to working on world class open source software, there is a strong desire to bring those practices back inside the firewall and apply them to software that companies may be reluctant to release. For companies building mostly closed source software, InnerSource can be a great tool to help break down silos, encourage internal collaboration, accelerate new engineer on-boarding, and identify opportunities to contribute software back to the open source world.
title: What is Innersource?

Bristol Rovers are a professional association football team based in [Bristol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bristol), England. Founded in 1st August 1883. They **dominate** the third tier of English football. Their home stadium the world famous [Memorial Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_Stadium_(Bristol)).

![](https://stackoverflow.com/c/pickles/images/s/c68202c8-5da1-45d8-9887-ede5b556c77a.png)

The clubs official nickname is "The Pirates", reflecting the maritime history of Bristol. The local nickname of the club is "The Gas", derived from the gasworks next to their former home, [Eastville Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastville_Stadium "Eastville Stadium"), which started as a derogatory term used by fans of their [main rivals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bristol_derby "Bristol derby"), [Bristol City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bristol_City_F.C. "Bristol City F.C."), but was affectionately adopted by the club and its supporters. [Cardiff City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiff_City_F.C. "Cardiff City F.C.") and [Swindon Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swindon_Town_F.C. "Swindon Town F.C.") are considered their [second](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severnside_derby "Severnside derby") and [third biggest rivals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bristol_Rovers_F.C.%E2%80%93Swindon_Town_F.C._rivalry "Bristol Rovers F.C.–Swindon Town F.C. rivalry").

> * Rovers were admitted to the [Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_Football_League "English Football League") in 1920 and have played there ever since, *apart from spending the [2014–15 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_Football_Conference "2014–15 Football Conference") in the [Conference Premier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conference_Premier "Conference Premier").*
>
> * Their highest finishing positions were in 1956 and 1959, on both occasions ending the season in 6th place in [Division Two](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_League_Second_Division "Football League Second Division"), then the second tier of English football.
>
> * The club's honours include winning the [third tier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_winners_of_English_Football_League_One_and_predecessors "List of winners of English Football League One and predecessors") title twice, and the [fourth tier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_winners_of_English_Football_League_Two_and_predecessors "List of winners of English Football League Two and predecessors") play-off final once. Rovers have also been the [Football League Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EFL_Trophy "EFL Trophy") finalists twice.

# **Colours & Badge**

Bristol Rovers are known for their distinctive blue and white quartered shirts, which they have worn for most of their history. The current home kit consists of a light blue and white quartered shirt and white shorts, while the away kit is black and gold with the same colours as the trim.

In 2005, Rovers ran an [April Fools'](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_Fools%27_Day "April Fools' Day") joke on their official website, stating that the team's new away strip would be all pink. Although this was intended to be a joke, a number of fans petitioned the club to get the kit made for real, and also suggested that funds raised through the sale of the pink shirts should be donated to a breast cancer charity. Although the pink shirts were never used in a competitive fixture, they were worn for a [pre-season friendly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exhibition_game "Exhibition game") against [Plymouth Argyle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plymouth_Argyle_F.C. "Plymouth Argyle F.C.") in 2006.

A pirate features on both the club badge and the badge of the supporters club, reflecting the club nickname of The Pirates. Previous club badges have featured a blue and white quartered design, based on the quartered design of the team's jerseys.

![](https://stackoverflow.com/c/pickles/images/s/6da84d0c-b4c7-40c7-a763-8b11c04d5975.png)

# **Grounds**

* Purdown – 1883–1884

* Three Acres – 1884–1891

* Schoolmasters Cricket Ground – 1891–1892

* [Durdham Down](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durdham_Down "Durdham Down") – 1892–1894

* Ridgeway – 1894–1897

* [Eastville Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastville_Stadium "Eastville Stadium") – 1897–1986

* [Twerton Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twerton_Park "Twerton Park") – 1986–1996

* [The Memorial Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_Stadium_(Bristol) "Memorial Stadium (Bristol)") – 1996–present

# **Honours**

**Leagues**

* **[Southern League Division One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Football_League "Southern Football League"): Champions: 1**

1904–05

* **[Football League Third Division South](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_League_Third_Division_South "Football League Third Division South"): Champions: 1**

1952–53

* **[Football League Third Division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_League_Third_Division "Football League Third Division"): Champions: 1**

1989–90

* **[Football League Two](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_League_Two "Football League Two") play-offs: Winners: 1**

2007

* **[Conference Premier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conference_Premier "Conference Premier") play-offs: Winners: 1**

2015

**Cups**

* **[Football League Third Division South Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_League_Third_Division_South_Cup "Football League Third Division South Cup"): Winners: 1**

1934–35

* **[Football League Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_League_Trophy "Football League Trophy"): Runners-up : 2**

1989–90, [2006–07](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_Football_League_Trophy "2006–07 Football League Trophy")

* **[Watney Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watney_Cup "Watney Cup"): Winners : 1**

1972

* **[Gloucestershire Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gloucestershire_Cup "Gloucestershire Cup"): Winners: 32**

1888–89, 1902–03, 1904–05, 1913–14, 1924–25, 1927–28, 1934–35, 1935–36, 1937–38, 1947–48, 1948–49, 1950–51, 1953–54, 1954–55, 1955–56, 1958–59, 1962–63, 1963–64, 1964–65, 1965–66, 1967–68, 1973–74, 1974–75, 1981–82, 1982–83, 1983–84, 1984–85, 1988–89, 1989–90, 1992–93, 1993–94, 1994–95

## Records

**Scorelines**

* Biggest League Win:

  * **7–0** (v [Brighton & Hove Albion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brighton_%26_Hove_Albion_F.C. "Brighton & Hove Albion F.C."), Division Three (South), 29 November 1952)

  * **7–0** (v [Swansea City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swansea_City_A.F.C. "Swansea City A.F.C."), Division Two, 2 October 1954)

  * **7–0** (v [Shrewsbury Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shrewsbury_Town_F.C. "Shrewsbury Town F.C."), Division Three, 21 March 1964)

  * **7–0** (v [Alfreton Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfreton_Town_F.C. "Alfreton Town F.C."), Conference Premier, 25 April 2015)

* Biggest Cup Win:

  * Competition proper: **6–0** (v [Merthyr Tydfil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merthyr_Tydfil_F.C. "Merthyr Tydfil F.C."), FA Cup Round 1, 14 November 1987)

  * Qualifying: **15–1** (v [Weymouth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weymouth_F.C. "Weymouth F.C."), FA Cup Third Qualifying Round, 17 November 1900)

* Biggest League Defeat: **0–12** (v [Luton Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luton_Town "Luton Town"), Division Three South, 13 April 1936)

**Players**

* Most League Appearances: **546** – [Stuart Taylor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuart_Taylor_(footballer_born_1947) "Stuart Taylor (footballer born 1947)"), 1966–1980

* Most Goals for club: **242** – [Geoff Bradford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoff_Bradford "Geoff Bradford"), 1949–1964

* Most Goals in a season: **33** – Geoff Bradford, 1952–53

  ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Geoff_Bradford.jpg/170px-Geoff_Bradford.jpg)Bristol Rovers record goalscorer, [Geoff Bradford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoff_Bradford "Geoff Bradford"). Picture taken in 1988, when he was 61 years old.

* Highest [Transfer Fee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_(football) "Transfer (football)") Paid: **£375,000** – [Andy Tillson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Tillson "Andy Tillson") from Queens Park Rangers, November 1992

* Highest Transfer Fee Received: **£2,600,000** – [Barry Hayles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_Hayles "Barry Hayles") to Fulham, November 1998

**Other**

* Record Home Attendance: **38,472** (v [Preston North End](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preston_North_End_F.C. "Preston North End F.C."), [FA Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup"), 30 January 1960

# Notable Former Players

![](https://stackoverflow.com/c/pickles/images/s/1c845066-239e-4bf6-833a-50ce83e4e5e5.png)Jamie Cureton, 1996-2000. 168 appearances, 68 goals.
title: Bristol Rovers - A history
body:
Bristol Rovers are a professional association football team based in Bristol, England. Founded in 1st August 1883. They dominate the third tier of English football. Their home stadium the world famous Memorial Stadium.

The clubs official nickname is "The Pirates", reflecting the maritime history of Bristol. The local nickname of the club is "The Gas", derived from the gasworks next to their former home, Eastville Stadium, which started as a derogatory term used by fans of their main rivals, Bristol City, but was affectionately adopted by the club and its supporters. Cardiff City and Swindon Town are considered their second and third biggest rivals.

  • Rovers were admitted to the Football League in 1920 and have played there ever since, apart from spending the 2014–15 season in the Conference Premier.

  • Their highest finishing positions were in 1956 and 1959, on both occasions ending the season in 6th place in Division Two, then the second tier of English football.

  • The club's honours include winning the third tier title twice, and the fourth tier play-off final once. Rovers have also been the Football League Trophy finalists twice.

Colours & Badge

Bristol Rovers are known for their distinctive blue and white quartered shirts, which they have worn for most of their history. The current home kit consists of a light blue and white quartered shirt and white shorts, while the away kit is black and gold with the same colours as the trim.

In 2005, Rovers ran an April Fools' joke on their official website, stating that the team's new away strip would be all pink. Although this was intended to be a joke, a number of fans petitioned the club to get the kit made for real, and also suggested that funds raised through the sale of the pink shirts should be donated to a breast cancer charity. Although the pink shirts were never used in a competitive fixture, they were worn for a pre-season friendly against Plymouth Argyle in 2006.

A pirate features on both the club badge and the badge of the supporters club, reflecting the club nickname of The Pirates. Previous club badges have featured a blue and white quartered design, based on the quartered design of the team's jerseys.

Grounds

  • Purdown – 1883–1884

  • Three Acres – 1884–1891

  • Schoolmasters Cricket Ground – 1891–1892

  • Durdham Down – 1892–1894

  • Ridgeway – 1894–1897

  • Eastville Stadium – 1897–1986

  • Twerton Park – 1986–1996

  • The Memorial Stadium – 1996–present

  • Gloucestershire Cup: Winners: 32

1888–89, 1902–03, 1904–05, 1913–14, 1924–25, 1927–28, 1934–35, 1935–36, 1937–38, 1947–48, 1948–49, 1950–51, 1953–54, 1954–55, 1955–56, 1958–59, 1962–63, 1963–64, 1964–65, 1965–66, 1967–68, 1973–74, 1974–75, 1981–82, 1982–83, 1983–84, 1984–85, 1988–89, 1989–90, 1992–93, 1993–94, 1994–95

Records

Scorelines

    • 7–0 (v Brighton & Hove Albion, Division Three (South), 29 November 1952)

    • 7–0 (v Swansea City, Division Two, 2 October 1954)

    • 7–0 (v Shrewsbury Town, Division Three, 21 March 1964)

    • 7–0 (v Alfreton Town, Conference Premier, 25 April 2015)

  • Biggest Cup Win:

    • Competition proper: 6–0 (v Merthyr Tydfil, FA Cup Round 1, 14 November 1987)

    • Qualifying: 15–1 (v Weymouth, FA Cup Third Qualifying Round, 17 November 1900)

  • Biggest League Defeat: 0–12 (v Luton Town, Division Three South, 13 April 1936)

Players

body_markdown:
Overview 

Teams give you and your team members an area to work collaboratively, together towards a common goal. Teams are a perfect place to ask questions that don’t have universal answers. In other words, if you have a question that would not make sense outside of your team, or is perhaps sensitive information that should not be visible to your entire Community, Teams is the perfect place. 

# Strategy: when to use

Before creating a team, it's good practice to think about a goal or project and the people who can help deliver it collaboratively. Try to avoid creating different teams that have the same set of members, since this approach may not provide the desired focus to meet the goal. Once you've created your team, let people know where to contribute and to find existing conversations.

Teams can be dynamic for project-based work as well as ongoing, to reflect the internal structure of your organization.

**Possible use cases for Teams:**

* Support: Issue Management

* HR: Recruiting

* Product: Strategy

* Logistics: Operations

* Events: Conference planning

Remember, questions and information posted within a team area are only visible to members of that team. Membership to teams is by invite-only by the Team Owner. If you do have a question that makes sense outside of your team, it’s best to ask in the general Community area instead to avoid locking away that knowledge in private silos. 

# How to use

There are two main roles in Teams: a *Team Owner*, the person who creates the strategy for the team, and *Team Members*, the people who they invite to join their team. Only your *Community Administrator* has the ability to create a Team.

**What can an Administrator do?**

* **Create teams**

  [![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583356/original/Z5EyQ3yqsVUT-239WtyykVj5rcBAXNiBxw.gif?1538415789)](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583356/original/Z5EyQ3yqsVUT-239WtyykVj5rcBAXNiBxw.gif?1538415789)

* **Manage all teams** from their *Global Settings* area, at all times (See **What can a Team Owner do?**)

![](https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/03cJCO-hrezuS5A1MFonp50Q1UQJd1tB1qkDYrwwgVUIjgHzftVxivmiYao6PChbkL87b2IfqxQvody-s7Dr5uDaEeO9UegmtwTyqza4q36rr-m2a5nwE5VpP8WXwD3OS78BUiQK)

* See the Teams in the left nav bar if they are a member or an owner

* Update Team Site Settings - to update site settings like *Ask Question* Sidebar text, Admins can go to the team and append - *‘developer/site-settings’*  to make specific changes

* Update site name under *Global Settings > Site Settings > Site Name*

**What can a Team Owner do?**

* Set a team purpose and strategy

* Review and edit the starter questions

* **Invite new team members**

  [![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583683/original/AnFiq34-MZ0vKA_rhVtq8yAKSA2Yl_NzSw.gif?1538416012)](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583683/original/AnFiq34-MZ0vKA_rhVtq8yAKSA2Yl_NzSw.gif?1538416012)

* **Remove team members**

  **[![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583736/original/9dWLQ_edyUWdK6KdSd1RKNyCJZ0_6M_kxw.gif?1538416081)](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583736/original/9dWLQ_edyUWdK6KdSd1RKNyCJZ0_6M_kxw.gif?1538416081)**

* **Restore a removed team member**

  [![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583811/original/d0F_dln3F9ISCYOlr9jOeCv7nTDDUfKzcQ.gif?1538416172)](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22026583811/original/d0F_dln3F9ISCYOlr9jOeCv7nTDDUfKzcQ.gif?1538416172)

**What happens when a User is removed from a Team**

* Once removed, content becomes anonymous but remains. Team Owners can reactivate the deleted user from their dashboard.

* There must be at least one Team Owner for a Team at all times. The system will not allow you to revoke owner status if you are the only owner on the team.

# Other features

**Mentioning/Notifying** 

Connecting questions with people who can answer them can be more challenging when the audience is small, so we’ve incorporated a feature that addresses discoverability. Within a Team, users can notify colleagues about questions they may be interested in or for which they may be able to provide answers. This feature is available inside a Team and in the general area of your Community.

![](https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/99JpV3pHf-hQkSbKU-Tt7zj9PTvYYEDgdiLsKb4AYxTlp-3uMfFK5HDbuWnzfw1mOqIy0I4ho8ADDa0dvmxlLVlxweZhOqrC0-0yK0Fq5n0BzoaGINYIGB9T6BqTyhQ_nJlcW6qo)

**Onboarding: Banners, Checklists, and Starter Questions. Oh my!**

We’ve included some built-in guidance to assist you with onboarding. This includes prompts and information on how the Teams feature works as well as starter questions that you can edit to provide additional guidance for your users.

![](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/_7j5HSoxEzvefu465NRPLW_Xjj1e0yZeQ055yznne1M8aYsKukHM_zMIbrhdCTl2cXpXBI7WocdN7tyapwmX6wPGUtsePlfzbtxq8Ci6oVS-nyvMui0P-F93GhwAOu1jXBAVb7RM)

**Team Emails** 

Email notifications are part of this new feature functionality but you can turn off specific emails inside a Team if you don’t want people to get it. Your Administrator can can go to the team and append *‘developer/site-settings’* to  turn off specific emails.

The new emails include:

* Welcome Email - Team Owner

* Welcome Email - User

* You have been removed from the Team

* You’ve been mentioned - inbox notification

* Your answer was accepted

* Your question has been answered
title: Teams on Enterprise

The annual license for Stack Overflow Enterprise includes ongoing coverage and technical support for the software application and its performance. This document documents the response that Stack Overflow will take to reported issues with the software, along with a categorization of issue severity.

All issues should be initially reported to Stack Overflow by emailing enterprise-support@stackoverflow.com.

Once a case has been opened, Stack Overflow will provide support communication via e-mail or phone to address and resolve the issue as appropriate.

body_markdown:
Hello Stackers!

Our newest feature - ‘Teleporting (beta)’ **launched** today !

![](https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/D1F4X4GhA3MV05koSX-Ns1w_ryXG0-dpZCaxmPWLu8FmEsvmrhhm5ywn1RZGSBGUVFk4VdBJUL8FwkzHTlaVQhBDltSY1B-e0gy7QWuPFmPaqOKorcZoL2Q59VwDbr8nuHH4p7Mi)

**What is Teleporting?**

Quantum teleportation is a process in which quantum information (e.g. the exact state of an atom or photon) can be transmitted (exactly, in principle) from one location to another, with the help of classical communication and previously shared quantum entanglement between the sending and receiving location. Because it depends on classical communication, which can proceed no faster than the speed of light, it cannot be used for faster-than-light transport or communication of classical bits. While it has proven possible to teleport one or more qubits of information between two (entangled) quanta, this has not yet been achieved between anything larger than molecules. (source:[ Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_teleportation))

**Why beta?**

We recommend only teleporting non-living things in beta, and not use humans or animals yet.

**Will there be a V2 of this Feature?**

Yes! We will be adding the ability to teleport living beings, teleporting in groups, and opening more gateways in addition to other features based on customer feedback, over the next few releases.

**Who is this feature for?**

❌ Product name

❌ Product name - tier 1

✅ Product name - tier 2

✅ Product name - tier 3

*Note: The feature is currently in beta, and not live to all customers yet.*

**Where can I find out more?**

Find out more in these supporting FAQs:

* <https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16548>

* <https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16524>

**Shout outs?**

Many thanks to **John Doe** who worked diligently on this feature!

body_markdown:
Hello Stackers!

Our newest feature - ‘Teleporting (beta)’ **launched** today !

![](https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/D1F4X4GhA3MV05koSX-Ns1w_ryXG0-dpZCaxmPWLu8FmEsvmrhhm5ywn1RZGSBGUVFk4VdBJUL8FwkzHTlaVQhBDltSY1B-e0gy7QWuPFmPaqOKorcZoL2Q59VwDbr8nuHH4p7Mi)

**What is Teleporting?**

Quantum teleportation is a process in which quantum information (e.g. the exact state of an atom or photon) can be transmitted (exactly, in principle) from one location to another, with the help of classical communication and previously shared quantum entanglement between the sending and receiving location. Because it depends on classical communication, which can proceed no faster than the speed of light, it cannot be used for faster-than-light transport or communication of classical bits. While it has proven possible to teleport one or more qubits of information between two (entangled) quanta, this has not yet been achieved between anything larger than molecules. (source:[ Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_teleportation))

**Why beta?**

We recommend only teleporting non-living things in beta, and not use humans or animals yet.

**Will there be a V2 of this Feature?**

Yes! We will be adding the ability to teleport living beings, teleporting in groups, and opening more gateways in addition to other features based on customer feedback, over the next few releases.

**Who is this feature for?**

❌ Product name

❌ Product name - tier 1

✅ Product name - tier 2

✅ Product name - tier 3

*Note: The feature is currently in beta, and not live to all customers yet.*

**Where can I find out more?**

Find out more in these supporting FAQs:

* <https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16548>

* <https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16524>

**Shout outs?**

Many thanks to **John Doe** who worked diligently on this feature!
title: Product Announcement: Teleportation is here!
body:
Hello Stackers!

Our newest feature - ‘Teleporting (beta)’ launched today !

What is Teleporting?

Quantum teleportation is a process in which quantum information (e.g. the exact state of an atom or photon) can be transmitted (exactly, in principle) from one location to another, with the help of classical communication and previously shared quantum entanglement between the sending and receiving location. Because it depends on classical communication, which can proceed no faster than the speed of light, it cannot be used for faster-than-light transport or communication of classical bits. While it has proven possible to teleport one or more qubits of information between two (entangled) quanta, this has not yet been achieved between anything larger than molecules. (source: Wikipedia)

Why beta?

We recommend only teleporting non-living things in beta, and not use humans or animals yet.

Will there be a V2 of this Feature?

Yes! We will be adding the ability to teleport living beings, teleporting in groups, and opening more gateways in addition to other features based on customer feedback, over the next few releases.

Who is this feature for?

❌ Product name

❌ Product name - tier 1

✅ Product name - tier 2

✅ Product name - tier 3

Note: The feature is currently in beta, and not live to all customers yet.

Where can I find out more?

Find out more in these supporting FAQs:

  • https://soedemo.stackenterprise.co/questions/16548

  • How do I use the JIRA Enterprise integration?

Shout outs?

Many thanks to John Doe who worked diligently on this feature!

body_markdown:
**(Version 2020.2 and later)**

Starting with Stack Overflow Enterprise [2020.2](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000258052-2020-2-08-04-2020), Site Admins can create "user groups" so users can easily mention and notify a set of other users. If you'd like to use this feature and aren't yet on 2020.2 or higher, please [reach out to support](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/tickets/new) to get upgraded. 

## Introduction

Organizations often have different groups of users responsible for different parts of their service. When questions arise under that group's area of expertise, pinging each user individually or picking and choosing who might be the best option can be cumbersome. We've introduced user groups as a method to allow you to reach out to entire groups of users with a single name, rather than individually pinging them all. With careful usage and management of user groups, you can ensure all people who need to know about certain inquiries are informed of it, even as your organization grows and changes over time.

The general area of Stack Overflow Enterprise is a one namespace for user groups, and each [private Team](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000227004) (if the [Teams](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000227004) feature is enabled on your instance) is also a separate namespace for user groups. Site Admins can manage user groups for the general area by clicking Admin Settings > User Groups (/enterprise/user-groups). Team Admins (i.e. Team Owners) can manage user groups for a private team by going to their team > Settings > Groups. View a searchable list of all groups by clicking on view user groups at the top of the Users page.

## Create and populate a new group

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060912580/original/MIitLDM_V3Oc6yoVrFwHOQeMS5E7It2NKg.png?1596559278)

The Manage Groups page will look like the above, though it will initially be empty. To start creating a new group, click the "Add user group" button. You'll be prompted with providing a Name for the group, and an optional Description. The Description is only visible to Admins in the Manage Groups page and is meant for book-keeping, but the Name is what your whole Team will see and use, so make sure it's reflective of what collection of people it needs to represent. 

Once you've created a user group, you'll be informed that there are no new users, and provided a button to "Add users to this group". Click the button, and you'll be provided a search field to add users.

Once you've added at least one user to your user group, you'll see them listed like the following image:

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060912581/original/rR6HBxpxFfR_64jMd9ikJPb5FJuiNrM9wg.png?1596559279)

## Modify a group

From the Manage Groups page, there's a few different management actions you can perform.

* To add or remove users from an existing group, click on the name of the group, or on the listed number of members for the group. This will take you to the page shown earlier above. New users can be added by clicking "Add users" in the top right. Users can be removed from the group by clicking "Remove" on the right of the user's entry on the table. Use these actions to ensure the membership of each group is kept up to date.

* To rename a group, or to change its description, click "Edit" on the right side of the table entry for the group. This will bring up a prompt with the group's current name and description that can be edited.

* To delete a group, click "Delete" on the far right. Deleting a group will not affect any of the users in the group, but it will make the group no longer usable in the Q&A and remove any existing notification mentions of the group used in questions or answers. 

## Notify an entire group

Once your User Groups are created as suits your needs, you can then use them in regular Q&A as a method to notify all the members of that group in one mention. When filling out a new question, the selection for "Ask team members" will now include any user groups as an option, like shown in the image below:

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060912579/original/zRkueXzs-hxT9HAvC3yqK52iTGPmAn2dhg.png?1596559278)

User Groups can also be referred to in comments or posts using @ in the same way you would notify any individual member of your Team.

## Questions

If you have any questions, please [reach out to support](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/tickets/new) for further guidance.
title: User Groups

Once you've added at least one user to your user group, you'll see them listed like the following image:

Modify a group

User Groups can also be referred to in comments or posts using @ in the same way you would notify any individual member of your Team.

Questions

body_markdown:
**(Version 2020.2 and later)**

Starting with Stack Overflow Enterprise [2020.2](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000258052-2020-2-08-04-2020), Stack Overflow allows users to create collections of questions and articles. If you'd like to use this feature and aren't yet on 2020.2 or higher, please [reach out to support](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/tickets/new) to get upgraded.

Use collections to group together questions and articles and display them in a list for easier viewing. Collections are designed to work alongside tags. While tags tend to identify a broader topic, collections can span multiple topics. For example, you might group all the on-boarding documentation for a particular position into one collection so that all of the questions are easy to find in one place, rather than creating tags for each position.

You can create collections in the general area of Stack Overflow Enterprise, or within a [Team](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/solutions/articles/22000227004) if the private Teams feature is enabled on your SOE instance.

## Create or modify a collection

**To create:** While viewing your team, visit the **Collections** section in the left sidebar and then click on **Create new collection** at the top right. You will be presented two boxes to enter a title and description, after which you will be taken to the full editor screen for the collection automatically.

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060926904/original/6P06QK-icjbdIU22eaGedRfVXwF2ggdd2Q.png?1596575041)

**To modify:** Visit the collection that you wish to edit and click on **Edit collection** at the top right. You will be presented the same editor as when the collection was created, allowing you to make any changes.

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060928298/original/NIcQ8g-X5aiZzOAGPwkY9mE3_fHqjUEhng.png?1596576768)

While editing the collection, you can add new questions to appear inside it using the search box or delete questions from the list below. You can also use the six dots to drag questions up and down to manually order them in the list. All changes to questions are immediate - you only need to click **Save** at the top when making changes to the title or description.

If the collection is no longer useful, you can also **Delete** the collection from this page.

## Share a collection externally

Visit the collection that you wish to edit and click on **Share collection** at the top right. A dialog will appear with a link to the collection that can be shared anywhere, both within your team and outside Stack Overflow.

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060926906/original/WjhoKeN67_bQskpTg6MudeZ3m1zlOEgzQg.png?1596575041)

**Note:** Your personal user ID number for the team is attached to the end of the URL for tracking purposes. It is not required and can be removed from the URL if desired.

## Control who can edit

While editing a collection, you can click on **Sharing settings** at the top right to open a new dialog. These settings allow you to change the owner of the collection as well as specify users and groups that can edit and view the collection.

![](https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.freshdesk.com/data/helpdesk/attachments/production/22060926903/original/at0EcV-ffPt2Q2XfsrnC_Vlo34PiBBHpLQ.png?1596575041)

By default, if no other permissions are specified, the collection can be viewed by everyone in your team but edited only by the user who created it.

### Search collections

At this time, collections are not searchable. However, the individual questions present in a collection will still appear in search as normal.

## Questions

If you have any questions, please [reach out to support](https://support.stackenterprise.co/support/tickets/new) for further guidance.

Note: Your personal user ID number for the team is attached to the end of the URL for tracking purposes. It is not required and can be removed from the URL if desired.

Control who can edit

While editing a collection, you can click on Sharing settings at the top right to open a new dialog. These settings allow you to change the owner of the collection as well as specify users and groups that can edit and view the collection.

By default, if no other permissions are specified, the collection can be viewed by everyone in your team but edited only by the user who created it.

Search collections

At this time, collections are not searchable. However, the individual questions present in a collection will still appear in search as normal.

Questions

If you have any questions, please reach out to support for further guidance.

body_markdown:
Adapted from the [looker docs](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/presenting-content).

Viewing and Managing Access to a Board

Presenting Content with Boards

**Boards** in Looker provide a way for teams to find curated and . Dashboards and Looks, which are stored in , can be pinned to multiple boards. Boards provide a way for users to:

Users will only see boards that they have access to view. A user must have the **View** access level to see a board. Users with the **Manage Access, Edit** access level can pin dashboards and Looks to the board and provide context for that content to help guide other users.

Access to boards and the content that is pinned to them, like Looks or dashboards, depends on a user or group’s board access, their [access to the folder in which that content is stored](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/organizing-spaces#viewing_and_managing_access_for_a_space), and the [model the Look or dashboard is based on](https://docs.looker.com/admin-options/settings/roles#model_sets).

If a user doesn’t have folder access for viewing a dashboard or Look, that dashboard or Look will not be displayed to that user on the board. If the user has folder access but not model access, they will see a thumbnail but will not be able to view the underlying Look or dashboard.

## Board Access Levels

There are two access levels that can be assigned to a [user](https://docs.looker.com/admin-options/settings/users) or [group](https://docs.looker.com/admin-options/settings/groups) for a board: **View** and **Manage Access, Edit**.

With the **View** access level, a user can see that the board exists, add the board to their list, and view any pinned content that they have [access to view](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/organizing-spaces#viewing_and_managing_access_for_a_folder).

With the **Manage Access, Edit** access level, a user can do everything that the **View** access level allows, plus make the following changes to the board:

* Manage access to the board

* Organize and manage content on the board

* Pin and remove Looks and dashboards

* Delete the board

## Viewing the Access Levels for a Board

To view the access levels that other users and groups have for a board, you must have the **Manage Access, Edit** access level for that board. To see who can access a board:

1. Navigate to the board. In the upper right of the board, to the right of the board’s title and to the left of the three-dot menu and information icon, select the share icon.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-share-menu-618.png)

2. Looker displays the **Manage access** window for the board.

3. In the **Who can access this board?** section of the window, you can see a list of users and groups who have access to the board as well as their access levels.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-manage-access-624.png)

## Managing the Access Levels for a Board

To manage access to a board, you need the **Manage Access, Edit** access level for that board. To make changes to the access level a group or user has for a board:

1. Navigate to the board and view its access levels by selecting the share icon.

2. To change the access level for a user or group that is already listed, select their current access level and choose the desired access level from the menu. You cannot change the ability of Looker admins to manage the board.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-manage-access-existing-624.png)

3. Remove user or group access by clicking the **X** beside the name.

4. Add one or more groups or users by selecting the **Add group or user** field, choosing a group or user, then selecting the desired access level.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-add-group-user-620.png)

5. Save your changes by selecting **Save**.

# Creating a Board

By default, when a board is created, admins and the creator have the **Manage Access, Edit** access level, and all other users can interact with the board at the **View** access level.

To create a new board:

1. Select the plus icon in the **Browse** menu or in the left sidebar in **Browse**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-create-board-plus-icon-620.png)

2. In the **Create board** window, enter a name for your board.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-create-board-window-620.png)

3. Select **Create board**. Looker then adds the new board to your list to the **Boards** section of the Browse menu and left sidebar navigation.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-new-board-in-nav-620.png)

   As the creator of the board, you will also be listed as a contributor in the **Contributors** section of the **About this board** information panel:

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-create-board-contributor-620.png)

You can then manage the content on the board such as adding sections, pinning Looks and dashboards, creating an information section, or managing access to the board.

# Adding a Board to Your List

You can create a shortcut to a board created by another user by adding that user’s board to a personal list of boards in your Browse menu, similar to a Favorites section. When you add a board to your list, the board will be listed under **Boards** in the Browse menu and the left navigation when you browse content in Looker. To add a board to your list, select **Add to my list** beneath the title of the board:

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-add-to-list-620.png)

To remove a board from your list, select the board’s three-dot menu and choose **Remove from my list**:

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-remove-from-list-620.png)

The number of users who have added a board to their list is reflected in the **About this board** section of the board’s information section:

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-added-to-list-620.png)

# Arranging Content on a Board

To arrange the content on a board, you must have the **Manage Access, Edit**access level. In addition to pinning Looks and dashboards to a board, contributors to a board can arrange the content on a board in the following ways:

* Add sections

* Reorder sections

* Remove sections

* Move content within sections

* Drag and drop pinned content between sections

If you make changes to a board, you will be listed as a contributor in the **Contributors** section of the **About this board** information panel:

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-board-contributors-620.png)

## Adding Sections to a Board

When you create a board, there is a default section named **Untitled section**. To edit the name of the section, choose the pencil icon to the right of the name of the board. You can then give the section a new name.

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-untitled-section-board-620.png)

To add a new section to a board, select **New section** at the bottom of your board. When you have entered a name for your new section, you can press Enter or return to save the name.

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-boards-new-section-620.png)

You can then begin to pin Looks and dashboards to the new section.

## Reordering Sections on a Board

To change the order of the sections on a board:

1. Hover over the section you want to move and select the vertical six-dot icon to the left of the section title.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-six-dot-icon-620.png)

2. Holding the vertical six-dot icon, drag the section to position it above or below another section.

## Removing Sections from a Board

If you have the **Manage Access, Edit** access level for a board, you can also delete its sections. To remove a section from a board:

1. Select the trash icon for the section you want to delete:

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-trash-icon-620.png)

2. Looker then displays a window to confirm that you want to delete the section.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-delete-section-window-620.png)

> *warning*
>
> Removing a section from a board also removes any Looks or dashboards that have been pinned to the board in that section. However, the Looks and dashboards still exist in their [folders](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/organizing-spaces).

## Moving Content Within Sections on a Board

To change the order of pinned Looks and dashboards within a section of a board:

1. Click on the Look or dashboard that you want to move.

2. Holding the pinned Look or dashboard, drag and drop it within the section of the board that it was pinned to.

## Moving Content Between the Sections of a Board

You can move a pinned Look or dashboard from one section to another by dragging and dropping the content you want to move. To move a pinned Look or dashboard from one section to another:

1. Select the pinned Look or dashboard that you want to move.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-drag-drop-select-76.png)

2. Holding the pinned Look or dashboard, drag it until it is positioned within the desired section of the board. If you hover over the new section while holding the Look or dashboard you are moving, Looker displays a message informing you that the Look or dashboard will be placed at the end of the section.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-drag-to-new-section-76.png)

3. Drop the Look or dashboard into the desired section. The Look or dashboard will be added to the end of that section.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-end-of-section-76.png)

# Adding Descriptions to a Board

For boards that you have created or for which you have **Manage Access, Edit**access, you can add a description that will appear in the board’s information panel and in the window that Looker displays when you [view all boards](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/finding-content#viewing_all_boards). You can also add a description to each section of a board.

## Adding a Description for the Entire Board

In the **About this board** information panel of a board, you can add a text description that will appear in the **Description** section. This description can be seen by anyone who can view the board and is a great way to give people context around the data pinned to the board. Your description can be up to 250 characters long and can include URLs and Markdown links.

To add or edit a board’s description:

1. Select the information icon (the letter **i** within a circle) to open the board’s informational panel.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-information-icon-620.png)

2. Under **Description**, select the **Add a description** text to add a new description.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-add-description-620.png)

3. To edit an existing description, hover over the description and select the pencil icon.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-description-pencil-620.png)

4. Add a description and select **Done** to save the description.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-new-description-620.png)

## Adding Descriptions to the Sections of a Board

You can add or edit descriptions for each of the sections of a board that you have created or for which you have **Manage Access, Edit** access. To add or edit a description to one of a board’s sections:

1. Select the **Add description** text beneath the section title.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-add-section-description-70.png)

2. Type in a description of up to 1,300 characters for the section and press the Return key to save the description.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-enter-section-description-70.png)

3. The description you have added will display beneath the title of the section.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-saved-section-description-70.png)

Users with **Manage Access, Edit** access to a board can modify an existing section description by selecting the existing text and performing the steps outlined above.

# Pinning Content to a Board

You can pin Looks and user-defined dashboards that are stored within existing folders, as well as LookML dashboards, to a board that you created or have access to edit. You can also unpin content from a board once it has been pinned.

Other users will be able to see and interact with pinned content if they have [access to it](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/organizing-spaces#viewing_and_managing_access_for_a_folder). Because content is stored in folders rather than on boards, adding and removing content from boards does not actually affect the underlying content.

If you pin content to a board, you will be listed as a contributor in the **Contributors** section of the **About this board** information panel:

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-board-contributors-620.png)

## Pinning Looks and User-Defined Dashboards to a Board

There are three ways to pin Looks and [user-defined dashboards](https://docs.looker.com/dashboards/creating-user-dashboards) to a board:

* Pinning from the board

* Pinning from a Look or dashboard’s thumbnail in a folder

* Pinning from the Look or dashboard’s gear menu

### Pinning from a Board

To pin a Look or dashboard to a board while you are viewing or editing the board:

1. If the section already has pinned content, hover over the section and select the **+** icon.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-plus-icon-pin-620.png)

   If the section doesn’t have any pinned content, select the **Pin a Dashboard or Look** text.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-pin-to-empty-620.png)

2. In the **Pin a Look or Dashboard** window, select the Look or dashboard that you want to pin to the board. The Look or dashboard you have selected will then appear in the section you have chosen.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-pin-look-dashboard-window-620.png)

### Pinning from a Folder

To pin a Look or dashboard to a board from a [folder](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/organizing-spaces) or from the Look or dashboard itself:

1. In a folder, select the three-dot menu on the thumbnail for the dashboard or Look you want to pin to a board and choose **Pin to a board**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-pin-from-folder-620.png)

2. Choose an existing board and section from the **Select a board** and **Select a section in the board** drop-down menus and select **Pin**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/pin-to-board-from-folder-620.png)

### Pinning from a Look or Dashboard

To pin a Look or dashboard that you are viewing to a board:

1. Select the gear menu to the right of the **Run** and **Edit** buttons and choose **Pin to a board**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/pin-from-look-or-dashboard-620.png)

2. Choose an existing board and section from the **Select a board** and **Select a section in the board** drop-down menus and select **Pin**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/pin-to-board-from-folder-620.png)

## Pinning LookML Dashboards to a Board

To pin a [LookML dashboard](https://docs.looker.com/dashboards/creating-lookml-dashboards) to a board:

1. Navigate to **All folders** in the **Browse** menu or left navigation.

2. Select the **LookML dashboards** folder and open the LookML dashboard that you want to pin.

3. From within the LookML dashboard, click the gear icon in the top right, and select **Pin to a board**. Select the board and section to which you would like to pin your LookML dashboard and then click **Pin**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-pin-lookml-620.png)

## Unpinning Looks and Dashboards from a Board

To remove a pinned Look or dashboard from a board:

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-unpin-from-board-620.png)

1. Select the three-dot menu on the Look or dashboard.

2. Choose **Unpin from this board**.

> *warning*
>
> If you remove a section from a board, any pinned Looks and dashboards in that section will also be removed.

# Sharing a Board

You can share boards for which you have the **Manage Access, Edit** access level by sharing a link to the board or by sending an email notification. Users must have at least the **View** access level for a board in order to view it.

## Sharing a Link to a Board

To obtain a link to a board that you can share with others:

1. Navigate to the board. In the upper right of the board, to the right of the board’s title and to the left of the three-dot menu and information icon, select the share icon.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-share-menu-618.png)

2. In the **Manage access** window, under **Share this board with someone**, select and copy the URL field, or click **Copy URL**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-share-board-620.png)

## Sending an Email Notification

When you grant a user access to a board, you are given the option of sending that user an email notification. If you add a user group to a board, however, email notifications will not be sent to the members of the group unless you also add the group members as individual users. To send an email notification: 

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-notification-checkbox-624.png)

1. In the **Manage access** window for the board, grant access to the user.

2. Select the **Email the people you have just added** checkbox.

3. Select **Save**.

Individual users you have added to the board will receive an email notifying them that they have been granted **View** or **Manage Access, Edit** access to the board. The email also invites users to view the board and encourages them to add it to their lists.

![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-boards-notification-624.png)

# Deleting a Board

> *warning*
>
> When you delete a board, you will not be able to recover it.

To delete a board, you must have the **Manage Access, Edit** access level. Deleting a board will not delete the Looks and dashboards that are pinned to the board, as they are stored in [folders](https://docs.looker.com/sharing-and-publishing/organizing-spaces). To delete a board:

1. Select the board’s three-dot menu and choose **Delete board**.

   ![](https://docs.looker.com/assets/images/presenting-content-delete-board-620.png)

2. Confirm that you want to delete the board in the window that Looker displays.

3.

Users will only see boards that they have access to view. A user must have the View access level to see a board. Users with the Manage Access, Edit access level can pin dashboards and Looks to the board and provide context for that content to help guide other users.

  2. In the Pin a Look or Dashboard window, select the Look or dashboard that you want to pin to the board. The Look or dashboard you have selected will then appear in the section you have chosen.

Pinning from a Folder

To pin a Look or dashboard to a board from a folder or from the Look or dashboard itself:

  1. In a folder, select the three-dot menu on the thumbnail for the dashboard or Look you want to pin to a board and choose Pin to a board.

  2. Choose an existing board and section from the Select a board and Select a section in the board drop-down menus and select Pin.

Pinning from a Look or Dashboard

To pin a Look or dashboard that you are viewing to a board:

  1. Select the gear menu to the right of the Run and Edit buttons and choose Pin to a board.

  2. Choose an existing board and section from the Select a board and Select a section in the board drop-down menus and select Pin.

Pinning LookML Dashboards to a Board

To pin a LookML dashboard to a board:

  1. Navigate to All folders in the Browse menu or left navigation.

  2. Select the LookML dashboards folder and open the LookML dashboard that you want to pin.

  3. From within the LookML dashboard, click the gear icon in the top right, and select Pin to a board. Select the board and section to which you would like to pin your LookML dashboard and then click Pin.

Unpinning Looks and Dashboards from a Board

To remove a pinned Look or dashboard from a board:

  1. Select the three-dot menu on the Look or dashboard.

  2. Choose Unpin from this board.

warning

If you remove a section from a board, any pinned Looks and dashboards in that section will also be removed.

Sharing a Board

You can share boards for which you have the Manage Access, Edit access level by sharing a link to the board or by sending an email notification. Users must have at least the View access level for a board in order to view it.

Sharing a Link to a Board

To obtain a link to a board that you can share with others:

  1. Navigate to the board. In the upper right of the board, to the right of the board’s title and to the left of the three-dot menu and information icon, select the share icon.

  2. In the Manage access window, under Share this board with someone, select and copy the URL field, or click Copy URL.

Sending an Email Notification

When you grant a user access to a board, you are given the option of sending that user an email notification. If you add a user group to a board, however, email notifications will not be sent to the members of the group unless you also add the group members as individual users. To send an email notification: 

  1. In the Manage access window for the board, grant access to the user.

  2. Select the Email the people you have just added checkbox.

  3. Select Save.

Individual users you have added to the board will receive an email notifying them that they have been granted View or Manage Access, Edit access to the board. The email also invites users to view the board and encourages them to add it to their lists.

Deleting a Board

warning

When you delete a board, you will not be able to recover it.

To delete a board, you must have the Manage Access, Edit access level. Deleting a board will not delete the Looks and dashboards that are pinned to the board, as they are stored in folders. To delete a board:

  1. Select the board’s three-dot menu and choose Delete board.

  2. Confirm that you want to delete the board in the window that Looker displays.
